Maniwaki, May the 1st, 1946.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Replying to your letter of April the 16, 1946, concerning the desk and the chair of the Maniwaki Indian Day School, I wish to inform you that although this desk and chair is in a good state the Teacher finds that this desk is altogether too high also the chair too low. When sitting at the desk she claims she nearly has to stand up to look at the children.

The teacher also states that there is no drawers to this desk and therefore no place to put any books. All these statements have been checked and found to be exact.

I have measured the stand carrying the desk and it is 47" wide by 56" long. Naturally if you intend furnishing a new desk, you will have to consider the stand or else get a new stand made altogether. This old desk is 40" wide by 23" deep.

J.R. Gendron,
Indian Agent.

This is to inform you that during the Easter Holidays both Schools were broken in and when the R.C.M.P. were here the other day I spoke to them about that. They answered that it would be advisable to have the Department ask for an inquest on this.

This is the third time the School was broken in at the Maniwaki Indian Day School and it is really time that something should be done about it. If whoever breaks into those schools is not checked now, we will be unable to keep anything in the schools.

Last Fall when this School was broken in it was found that School children had done this and this time if it is School children that have done it again I would like for the R.C.M.P. to take action in order to make an example.

J.E. Gendron, I.A.
Ottawa, May 11, 1946.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of a report from Mr. J. E. Gendron, Indian Agent, Maniwaki, in which he states that the two Indian Day Schools in the Maniwaki Agency were broken into during Easter week.

The Agent further states that this is the third time that someone has broken into the Maniwaki Day School.

Mr. Gendron spoke to the R.C.M.P. officials at Maniwaki, but they expressed the opinion that they should receive instructions from you before making any investigation.

I would appreciate it if you would issue such instructions to your officer at Maniwaki.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

The Commissioner,
Royal Canadian Mounted Police,
Ottawa, Ontario.

THE COMMISSIONER

FORWARDED FOR YOUR INFORMATION and that of the Department concerned, having reference to the Assistant D.C.I.'s memorandum of May 20th with Departmental letter attached. I suggest that court action be taken against these adults mentioned in paragraph eight who have admitted breaking into the school on or about April 23rd, 1946. You may consider authorizing prosecution under Section 539 of the Criminal Code or perhaps even under Section 461 of the Criminal Code, in view of the admission in Edgar Billot's statement to the effect that they broke in to get some cigarettes which indicates intention to steal. No action will be taken pending instructions.

STILL UNDER INVESTIGATION.

OTTAWA
1-6-46
EO

(F. W. Zaneth) Supt.,
Commanding "A" Division.
With reference to correspondence from the Director of Indian Affairs, dated 11-5-46, and forwarding minute appended thereto, regarding the captionally noted subject, the following enquiries were made. A patrol consisting of the writer and Cst. Richard proceeded to Maniwaki, P.Q., and visited Mr. J.R. Grendon, Indian Agent for the Maniwaki Band.

Mr. Grendon informed the writer that the Indian Day School had been broken into on three occasions, the latest being during the Easter Holidays, April 1946. Nothing apparently had been stolen during any of these breakings and enterings at the Day School; however, a sewing machine which was in the teachers quarters at the rear of the school was slightly damaged, and the place was left in a disorderly condition.

The School Teacher Miss. Marie Brennan, was contacted and stated that she had been employed at the Indian Day School since the first of the year, and confirmed the above information regarding the entering at Easter Time. Miss Brennan was asked for the names of any suspects, and she suggested Frank Meness, and Aime Baptiste.

After considerable questioning by Cst. Richard, and the writer it was finally learned that Aime Baptiste, age 12 yrs., Albert Chabot aged 15 yrs., and Edgar Chabot, aged 12 yrs., had been involved in breaking into this school during the berry season, which would be during the latter part of July or early August, 1946. A statement was taken from Aime Baptiste and Edgar Chabot, and are held on file at this office, the following are copies of the statements.

Maniwaki, P.Q.,
27-5-46.

Myself, Albert and Edgar Chabot were the ones who broke into the Indian Day School, Maniwaki Reserve. We only took six pencils, two each. Albert and I got on the roof of the back shed, but I did not break the window, and the window must have been broken by Albert. Edgar stayed on the ground the whole time.

Sdg. Aime Baptiste

Witness:
Sdg. R.W. Christy

Cont. Page 2.
Manawaki Que.
27-5-46.

Albert CHABOT my brother, and Aime BAPTISTE climbed onto the shed roof adjoining the Indian School, Manawaki, and my brother Albert went inside while I sat outside, watching when they came down they gave me two pencils which left them two each. This took place last fall sometime at about 3:00 p.m., I am not sure when.

Sgd. Edgar CHABOT

Witness:
R. W. Christy

5. Albert CHABOT was questioned and admitted his implication in this affair; no statement was taken from Albert other than verbally, which was to the effect that he corroborated the above statement. Albert admitted that he broke the window with a slingshot, and had entered the school, while the other boys remained outside, one of the roof and his brother on the ground.

6. These youngsters are Treaty Indians and live on the Reserve; their fathers are Andrew Baptiste, and Jim Chabot. Aime however resides with his grandfather, while the other two boys live with their parents.

7. The first time the school was broken into was during the spring of 1945, and was admittedly done by Aime BAPTISTE, Frank MENNESS age 13, and Patrick DUMONT age 10. No written statements were taken from these boys. From the stories given by them it would appear that a window was broken, the school entered and five pensiles stolen shortly after the school teacher had closed up and gone home for the night.

8. The Band Easter time was admittedly done by Edgar BILLIOT age 17, Tom BUCKSHOT age 18, Tom CHAUSSÉ age 15, and Charlie SMITH age 18, at about 5:00 a.m. on or about the 23rd of April 1946. The above subjects are all Treaty Indians with the exception of Edgar BILLIOT who is white, all subjects reside on the Indian Reserve. The fathers of the above are Rene BILLIOT, Ignace BUCKSHOT, Ellie CHAUSSÉ, and Charlie SMITH.

9. Statements were taken from the two principals and are set out hereunder; the originals are held on file here.

Manawaki Que.
28-5-46.

At about 5:00 a.m. in the morning I was returning from a party at Frank MENNESS home with Tom BUCKSHOT, Tom CHAUSSÉ, and Charlie SMITH when Tom BUCKSHOT said let's go into the school; may be there are cigarettes there. BUCKSHOT and I got on the shed roof and Tom broke the window with his fist, both went into the teachers rooms and down into the school room staying a short time & leaving right away. We did not take anything with us. This happened about the 22nd or 23rd of April on a Tuesday morning.

Sgd. Witness. E.J. Richard. Sgd. Edgar BILLIOT.
During the latter part of April Edgar BILLOT, Tom CHAUSSE, Charlie SMITH and I when on the way home from a party went into the Indian Day School. Edgar and I got on the roof of the shed and I broke the window with a stone that I had in my hand. Edgar and I went in and had a drink of water the other two fellows stayed on the ground. We did not take anything and left right away.

Witness. E.J. Richard.

Sgt. Thomas BUCKSHOT

10. Both BILLOT and BUCKSHOT claimed that neither had touched anything in the school building, especially the sewing machine. The reasons given by both these boys for entering the school are quite different and are obviously untrue.

11. Mr. J.R. GRENISON Indian Agent was advised of the findings of this patrol and requested that prosecutions be entered against Edgar BILLOT, Tom BUCKSHOT, Tom CHAUSSE, and Charlie SMITH, as he was of the opinion that an example should be made, as damage being done to the school, had become all too prevalent during the past year. Mr. GRENISON was advised that the facts, and his recommendations regarding this matter would be reported upon, by me, to my superiors for further instructions.

12. With regards the B.E. & Theft of the Conway Road School neither Mr. GRENISON, Indian Agent, nor the school teacher Miss Geraldine HOGAN had any suspects in mind. Miss. HOGAN advised that 2 dozen pencils, and some chalk had been stolen, and tentatively suggested the sons of Xavier COMANDO, Russell and Robert.

13. Russell and Robert COMANDO were questioned at length with negative results; neither boy spoke very good English, and no French. Russell aged 12yrs, and Robert aged 10yrs have not been attending school since. This matter was taken up with their mother, and she said that they did not want to attend therefore she had not made them. These boys cannot write, and have no use for pencils; no pencils were noted laying around their home, and it is believed they can be eliminated as suspects in the theft from the Conway Road School.

14. Several other boys of the Distr., who might be inclined to rowdyism were questioned at length by both members of the patrol, but nothing could be learned that would indicate any of them were guilty of the above offence.

15. The Conway School is not securely locked, as the lock on the door has been broken all this year, and is very easily opened. Miss Mildred TENESCO, who takes care of this school confirmed the above, as when asked if she had a key to enter the school in the mornings stated that one was not necessary.

Cont. Page 4.
Para 15 Cont.

not necessary owing to the lock being broken. Some of the Indians living close to the school have noticed the school door open on different occasions, and as the lock was broken believed that the wind had blown it open. Miss. HOGAN the school teacher when questioned regarding the loss of the pencils, and chalk, appeared rather uncertain that they had been stolen. It possible that after an absence of two weeks, Easter Holidays, that Miss. HOGAN was mistaken, however she thought not. In view of the lack of information on the B.E. & Theft at the Conway School it is considered that this enquiry should be concluded.

16. Instructions will be awaited as to what further action if any, is to be taken regarding this matter.

S.U.I.

H.W. Christy 10570 Cst.

The O.C."A" Div.
R.C.M.P.Ottawa, Ont.

Sir; Forwarded for your information and that of the Department concerned.

It is my belief that prosecution action is warranted against Edgar HILLIOT, Tom BUCKLETON, Tom CHAUSSE and Charlie SMITH at least under the provisions of the Criminal Code of Canada. As there is nothing to indicate that anything was stolen from the Indian Day School a charge under Section 430 of the Criminal Code of Canada would not stand. Also, as there is no evidence that there was any intent to commit an indictable offence it is felt that a charge under Section 438 of the Criminal Code of Canada would not be applicable.

It is my opinion that we could successfully enter prosecution under Section 539 of the Criminal Code of Canada. In any event I believe that some action should be taken in this regard as nothing else will have a deterrent effect on people of this type.

However, before taking any action instructions are awaited as to what charges, if any, are to be laid.

STILL UNDER INVESTIGATION.

J.J.Somers, Spl.9889
1/c Detachment

MEMORANDUM:

Re: Meniawaki Indian Day School.

In accordance with information supplied you in our memorandum of May 5th last, an officer from this Service visited the above on May 14th and following an inspection of the building and site, technical advice was given to the Indian Agent covering the proposed installation of a plumbing and drainage system.

No difficulties were encountered in arranging for new stairs to the basement and ample space was found in which to locate the plumbing fixtures. An arrangement of fixtures and partitions was sketched on print at the instruction of the Indian Agent. The fixtures recommended are as follows: two W.C.'s and one basin on boys' side; 2 W.C.'s and one basin on girls' side and one W.C. separately partitioned off for the teacher. A combination laundry tray and kitchen sink was suggested for the kitchen and one drinking fountain in the Class Room.

No suitable area was found where a septic tank and the customary disposal bed could be located without involving some blasting of rock formations and bulldozing operations in addition to a large quantity of gravel required, which would have to be trucked in and spread. Such an operation would be costly and out of all proportion to the total cost, and to the importance of the project.

The alternative, is to construct a rock pit or leeching well and connect the raw sewage line from the school thereto. This cess pit would be covered and after bacterial action has taken place, the effluent liquid would rise and be permitted to escape through the pit walls into the surrounding area. Such a pit would require examination and cleaning out after each school term.

A suitable location was found for a leeching well, and the ground slopes away from that point. This set up would be quite inexpensive, and has often been resorted to on jobs where similar conditions as described above were encountered.

The well diggers were at work and had gone down to an approximate depth of 50'-0" without finding water. Inquiry showed that some wells in that area are between 100'-0" and 150'-0" deep.

Until water in sufficient volume is found, no recommendation can be made regarding the type of pump required. The Agent was asked to communicate with the Indian Affairs Branch and advise as to the depth of water below grade, at which time the proper unit can be selected.

Re: Well for the Maniwaki Indian Day School.

This is to inform you that following our phone conversation of Saturday May the 10th, the well for the Maniwaki Indian Day School was started on Monday May the 12th, 1947. On my last visit there they had approximately 40 ft. drilled. I expect they may get water at approximately 100 ft., but no one can guarantee this.

The cost of this well is $6.00 a foot, complete with the casing whenever there is one needed. I have asked them for a well able to furnish approximately 200 to 300 gallons of water an hour, this is in view that some other Indians might want to connect on this system later on, or that the Band might decide to build other buildings in that location which might need water.

Whenever this well is finished I will immediately connect with the Department informing them of the deepness of this well and also to what height from the ground the water rises, in order that this information may be passed to the Engineer to enable him to recommend the pump needed for such a well.
When this first Maniwaki Indian Day School was located there, there should have been some understanding with the proprietor of the lot or the Band on which this School is built as to what dimension was allowed for the ground of this School. Would you have any records of this, if so could you let me know? I would like to know this on account of the projected Pit we would have to build outside of the School and going down the Hill, in order that this might be done on the ground allotted for this School, and if it is not possible get a piece of ground on the next lot, which is owned by an Indian. There seems to be no one around here which can give me this information and I have nothing in the records showing the exact dimensions of the grounds allotted for the School.

The Maniwaki Indian Day School is built on lot 23 Road Range West and the Congo Bridge Indian Day School is built on lot part of 34 Range 7 North of Congway Creek.

I also wish to inform that I had the visit of the Engineer regarding the ameliorations to be made at the Maniwaki Indian Day School and no doubt he will produce his report and recommendations shortly. Re: Well at the Maniwaki Indian Day School.

This is to inform you that the well at the Maniwaki Indian Day School is now finished.

We had to dig 130 ft. before sufficient amount of water could be reached and we have now a well that can furnish at least 35 gallons of water per minute. The digging of this well cost $6.00 per running foot, that is a total cost of $780.00. I have here Mr. J.P. Larocque's bill for the digging of this well, and I am keeping it here until I get written authorization from the Department to make a Voucher in Mr. Larocque's favour for this amount.

The water at present rises to about 20 ft. from the level of the ground and it is quite certain that an ordinary deep well pump installed in the cellar of the School will be sufficient to pump any amount of water we may need there either for the use of the School or any surrounding Indian habitation that may wish to use this water. Would you kindly connect with Mr. Hargreaves the engineer who absolutely wishes to know the height of the water in the well in order to recommend the right pump to be used. Kindly be sure to specify that this water at present cannot be lowered any more than 30 feet from the level of the ground and that at 40 ft. from the level of the ground it would be quite certain to have water at any time. Nevertheless it would be always recommendable to go as deep as possible with
a deep well pump providing it is a pump which could be put in the cellar of the School and avoid having to build a cabin over it, outside of the School.

I am quite positive that when the engineer has those informations, he will immediately know exactly what pump is necessary as this situation was discussed with him here in Maniwaki.

Personally I am very much satisfied with this well and I really believe it will satisfy our purpose, should the needs of water increase we will have a sufficient reserve for all emergencies.

J.E. Gendron,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

Re: Maniwaki Indian Day School, Quebec

We are in receipt of a memorandum from Indian Affairs in which is contained your report concerning the depth of the water below grade in connection with the new well at the above.

Basing our opinion on your report to the effect that water will always be available at a 40'-0" depth, we are pleased to advise you that a jet pump with pressure tank and complete auxiliary equipment, as hereinafter described, will be satisfactory for the job.

"One jet pumping unit equal to Crane Model #2 complete with 4 horsepower, 110-220 volt, 60 cycle, a.c. electric motor. This deep well jet pump system shall include pump head, slip coupling, ejector assembly, float valve and strainer, one 62 gallon pressure storage tank complete with gauge glass, pressure gauge; air volume control and connecting pipe and fittings between tank and pump head. Provide suitable automatic pressure switch to stop and start pump at 30 and 40 pounds per square inch.

Pump shall be capable of delivering 450 gallons per hour free flow, 415 gallons per hour against 20 pounds per square inch and 150 gallons per hour against maximum of 40 pounds per square inch. 1" drive pipe, 1½" suction pipe, 2" discharge pipe all suitable for 4" well casing.

All miscellaneous auxiliary items not specifically mentioned but which are necessary to give a complete installation shall be provided by the pump manufacturer who will be required to provide a complete set of instructions for installation purposes."

This pump and pressure tank is to be located in the basement at the nearest point to the well casing. Piping between well casing and pump to be laid below frost and precautions taken to prevent freezing. For your information the above unit should cost about $250.00 plus installation charges. One disconnect switch should also be provided.

Yours faithfully,

T.G. Mills,
Chief Engineer.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources
Ottawa, Ont.

Herein please find report on Form No. 1.A. 407 concerning the Maniwaki and the Congo Bridge Indian Day Schools.

I was asked by the Teacher and the children at the Maniwaki Indian Day School to furnish them a hose 200 ft. long 1" diameter to make a rink and also this hose could be used in the Summer time for watering around the School house. I would think this hose would be most suitable in rubber and after enquiries find that it would cost approximately .20 a foot. Should you think that the cost of this hose too expensive they might use the ½" hose but to water a small rink with ½" hose would be a long job.

Kindly let me know what you think of the idea?

J.E. Gendron,
Indian Agent.

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT.

Purchase Order No. 21923 -

Your File 74434-15-2 que.

Included in the list of plumbing supplies on the above purchase order are four closets (Vitreous China Tanks, etc.) We are informed by Regional Supervisor Gendron (former Indian Agent at Maniwaki) that Mr. Vaillancourt has not yet been able to provide all these closets and has only placed two in the school.

Extract from report of Russell Baker, Acting Superintendent, Maniwaki Indian Agency, dated April 6, 1948.

Maniwaki Indian Day School:

This school is a very good building which was improved considerably during the past year.

Attendance is very good. The teacher is very devoted and is quite successful. Good housekeeping should be taught and would strongly recommend that hot soups and drinks be given regularly to those pupils having lunch at school. This would be prepared by the older girls under the teacher's supervision and direction. This would be one efficient means of training for those girls.

A Junior Homemaker's Club should also be organized and the teacher should give such an organization much attention. Competitions in handicraft should be encouraged.

A small open air skating rink could be provided at a very low cost. Upkeep of which would be done exclusively by the pupils.

If this school was under the direction of a religious order such as the Grey Nuns, I am sure would be a step forward in the right direction. This possibility should be kept in mind and taken advantage of at first opportunity.

I acknowledge receipt of your letter of June 10th and further to our conversation regarding this matter, when we were in Golden Lake, I have taken the matter up with Mrs. Lee and she is quite willing to pay the difference in cost of electricity consumption if the department is willing to install the heater.

As mentioned in my letter of June 4th the cost of this unit installed would be $85.30, this would include a completely automatic thermostatically controlled heater.

Mrs. Lee would welcome a favourable reply to this request.

Mr. J.E. Gendron who was Indian Agent in Maniwaki informs me that last year the department had promised him to provide the installation of a well to provide water at the teacher's residence, Congo Bridge School and would also serve the purpose of the school.

Please advise if this project can go ahead this year. It would be highly commendable.

Yours very truly,

Russell Baker,
Acting Superintendent,
Indian Agency
July 12, 1948.

Mr. Russell Baker, Acting Superintendent,
Indian Agency, Maniwaki, Quebec.

Maniwaki Indian Day School.

Our records show the following accounts for electricity at the Maniwaki Indian Day School:

October 22 - December 5, 1947 $7.83
February 5 - April 3, 1948 $13.88
April 3 - June 1, 18.66

We do not seem to have a voucher covering the period December 5 to February 4; therefore, if we take the four months, February, March, April and May, the cost for electricity would be $8.00 per month. It would, therefore, be up to Mrs. Lee and succeeding teachers to pay any amounts of the electricity bills in excess of $8. per month.

If Mrs. Lee is willing to accept this arrangement, you may proceed to instal the unit mentioned in your letter at a cost of $85.30.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Indian Affairs Branch,

Ottawa, Canada

When at Golden Lake I was speaking to Mr. Neary about our intention to introduce into our Maniwaki Indian Day School as well as our Congo Bridge School hot drinks and food for the benefit of those children who have dinner at the school house.

This would serve also the purpose of training the older girls in the preparation of different dishes. As this is entirely new to this agency I will not venture in estimating what the cost of this will be.

As this is being practiced in other schools you are no doubt able to inform us of the approximate amount that will be allotted to each school. The Maniwaki Indian Day School has an attendance of approximately 30 children and the Congo Bridge School 20 school children, two-thirds of whom have lunch at school.

Supervisor J.E. Gendron left with me a blue print, index No. 888, dated Dec. 1948, for school building, including residence for teacher.

I have studied this plan and find it most suitable for our purposes to replace our old Congo Bridge School. As no residence is necessary for the Teacher I have reduced the length of the building to 46 feet, which would give a corridor of 7 feet 6 inches wide, instead of 5 feet, as mentioned on the plan. $6057.00 is estimated for this building.

Should your Department decide on building this school this fall, I would appreciate having your decision as soon as possible. The building of this school would not interfere in any way with the teaching in the old school.

Unless much delay is given this project at the Department I would be ready to start this building early in September and it would be completed by Nov. 1st.

Russell Baker,

MISTASSINI SUMMER SCHOOL

GENERAL
WHEN FORWARDING DAY SCHOOL RETURN FROM MR. GEORGE ISEHOF, TEACHER OF THE MISTASSINI SUMMER SCHOOL, FOR THE PERIOD JUNE 15th TO AUGUST 15th, 1939, RIGHT REV. J. G. ANDERSON, BISHOP OF MOOSONEE, STATES AS FOLLOWS:

"The teacher tells me in a personal letter that he has had a summer with many interruptions. Parties of the Indians had to go away from time to time to hunt for food, as they were all very hard up. Others went to Oskelaneo for their supplies to get cheaper goods, but it meant taking their families with them for weeks.

There were only about 18 of his pupils who were fairly regular, but even these were compelled to go away for fish, etc., in other parts, so that he had only 32 days for school. The rest of the time from June to August there were no children to teach, only a few being there. I think he should have kept school for them. Where there are seven days present and five absent for example means that these children could have attended 12 days, as they were in the camp. A number of others he did not enroll as they attended only 2 or 3 days at a time. Indians arrived late - about middle of June."
AGENT'S REPORT ON ABITIBI AGENCY FOR MONTH OF JUNE 1942.

I must note here the teacher in charge of our summer school, allows to remark that we will experience good results, an organization had been set up as requested by me, to provide women, girls with training for improved use of discarded military clothing, dress making, knitting and mending particularly.

H. Larivier,
Indian Agent.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I have just returned from my first Missionary trip to Waswanipe and Mistassini in Northern Quebec, and I thought I should write to you while the observations I wish to make are fresh in my mind.

In the first place, I am sorry to say that the school supplies which I ordered when I was in Ottawa more than two months ago had not arrived in time. I wrote to Mr. Phelan, who told me that the printers were behindhand, but that the supplies would be shipped as soon as possible. In the meantime, the teachers are on the spot and would do their best. I think I told you last year that at the two Missions I mentioned there are nearly a thousand Indians, very simple decent people, for whom comparatively little has been done in the educational way. [I have taken the Rev. Norman Burgomaster and left him at Mistassini, where there are six hundred Indians. The work there is a real challenge.] I have given instructions to the Hudson Bay Company to get out logs and lumber for a new church. The old building is not adequate at all, but I think it would do for a school to begin with, in fact it must be used for the present in that capacity. As we plan for the future, I feel that the Government and the Church ought to work together, and that we should understand each other. I could only stay a little over a day, and I found that Mr. Lariviere was there with a nurse. We were both so busy that it was difficult to have a confidential talk. I do not know him very well; I know he has very strong ideas about the health of the Indians; I believe he is genuinely anxious to help them. He is also a French Canadian, and the school is in the province of Quebec, but on the other hand, it is under the Department of Indian Affairs, which is a federal foundation, and the money spent for welfare and education comes from the pockets of the whole Canadian people. The Indians there speak Cree and a little English, but no French. I think it would be just and only fair, that in any development of schools or hospitals, the background and the history of the Indians should be considered. I am perfectly sure that if we were given the opportunity, it would be better for obvious reasons, if the Mission, the Hospital, and the school could work together.
There are several graduates of the Indian School at Chapleau, who have had some training at the Mothercraft Hospital in Toronto. It seems to me that there is a real vocation for some of the cleverer Indian girls. I think eventually that there should be a nurse at Mistassini, and possibly at Waswanipi, all the year round. An ordinary white girl on her own might find that difficult. Another alternative would be to give a decent grant and equipment to the Missionary's wife. There are several that I know who have some qualifications as Red Cross or St. John's Ambulance nurses, who would be able to do a great deal to keep the Department posted with regard to emergency cases requiring hospitalization outside, and do routine work on the spot.

I am going to be very busy this summer, and I hope to leave about the 15th of the month for James Bay. Would it be possible for us to talk the matter over in the Fall? I am most anxious and hopeful that I should be able to work with the Indian Agent who happens to be in charge of these two important posts, but I thought it better to speak to you before talking the matter over with him. He seems to be doing pioneer work, but it would be much more effective if we can work together.

I have ventured to send a copy of this letter to Dr. Moore, your Medical Superintendent, and I should be very glad if you could make any suggestions about having the matter cleared up, not only here but on James Bay at some convenient time.

I am very grateful for the help and for the kindness which has been shown to me since I came to Moosonee, and I would like to make some contribution towards the general good of our Indian fellow-citizens.

Yours faithfully,
St. John's Seasonal School,
Mistassini, via Roberval, P.Q.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

As the spring draws near, I wish to write to you about our plan for seasonal schools in the North Country. The following places are the ones we have chosen, all of which I mentioned to you when I called upon you in March.

1. Mistassini - 3½ or 4 months
2. Waswanipi - Lansdowne House 3½ or 4 months
3. Lansdowne House, Albany River do.
4. Collins and Fort Hope do.
5. Pickle Lake do.
6. Ombobika do.

A word of explanation about the various points. Lansdowne is the most distant point from the railroad, where we have had a church and school for several years. Mistassini and Waswanipi need no explanation. The Indians are all ours.

We will have to teach school for this summer in the church at both these places. I have associated Collins with Fort Hope; you will remember that last year we asked permission to follow the Indians when they left Fort Hope in July to go to Collins on the Railroad for the berry picking. The Indian Agent, Mr. Swartzman, approved this action. It may come to pass that Collins will be the headquarters for a considerable number of Indians in the future. Pickle Lake, which is sometimes called Pickle Crow, is a new mining centre where the Central Patricia Mines are gradually drawing Indians from Osnaburgh. We are anxious to begin work there this year. It looks as if it might become an all-year proposition before long. The last place, Ombobika, is rather special. The Ontario Government has a little school and teacher's house at this village on the C.N.R. A good number of Indians come down there for the summer. The teacher is willing to have an Indian school during the summer months. It is probably the only chance that the children will have for any teaching.

MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

Proposed Indian Day School at Mistassini

On November 18 the Right Reverend Robert J. Renison, M.A., D.D., Lord Bishop of Moosonee, visited this office to discuss educational plans in the Diocese of Moosonee. When informed that the Department was prepared to build an Indian Day School at Waswanipi, he informed us that he felt there was a more urgent need for a permanent day school at Mistassini. Not only are there more Indians at this latter point but they are a more stable group and a day school would have a better chance of success.

As a result of the meeting, the following decisions were reached:

1. That an educational survey be conducted by the Department as soon as possible to decide the location of this school.

2. That His Lordship be informed as soon as the necessary moneys have been made available for this purpose.

3. That a decision be deferred until the Spring as to whether the Department will be able to build this school or whether it will be necessary to appeal to the Church of England to have it constructed (as was the case at Fort McPherson).

On February 15th, 1947, Mr. Indian Agent Lariviere visited this office and the following proposals were made concerning the provision of Indian Day Schools at Mistassini and Waswasinipi.

The sum of $8,000 has been provided in the 1947-48 estimates for the construction of an Indian Day School at Waswasinipi. In view of the isolated position of both these schools it will not be possible to construct a frame building but it will be necessary to put up log buildings. It is further recommended that in view of the fire hazard which exists in these localities, that separate buildings be constructed for the teacherage and the school.

We therefore plan to proceed as follows with the expenditure of the $8,000 provided in the estimates:

(a) During the following summer logs will be cut by the Indians and hauled into position at Waswasinipi so that a start can be made in the construction of this school in the summer of 1948.

(b) During the following summer logs will be cut by the Indians and hauled into position at Mistassini so that a start can be made in the construction of this school in the summer of 1948.

In reply the suggestion of Rt. Rev. Bishop Rennison, is in accord, following conversation with him at Iroquois Falls and later in Ottawa, in presence of self and the Director Mr. R.A. Hoey, about 2 years ago.

The teachers at Mistassini I am still of the opinion should develop these Indians along practical lines, not altogether within the meaning of "school" as most persons understand it.

I believe teachers, man and wife, to teach these Indians as previously discussed, should both be paid, with the clear understanding that as soon proper set up is established, etc., that regular full time salaried teachers should take over, this should be possible at opening of summer season in 1949.

I wish to insist on this, that the set up at Mistassini must end and close up on August 15th, these Indians the majority have some 200 miles and more to move their supplies before freeze up and they should be all out of Mistassini before end of August, some of them by August 10th or about, holding them back like it has been done for a few years past, is detrimental to these Indians and a source of endless troubles, during winter, shortage of food etc., when pulling out too late, they don't get home to get the fish run and this means starvation, T.B. poverty and what not.

Dear Mr Neary;

When talking with Bishop Rennison of Moosonee recently he informed me of the developments at the Mistisinni Lake Reservation, P.Q. I was intensely interested as I spent some years in the Bay and at one time made the long hard trip by canoe from Rupert's House to Mistissini.

I wonder if you will mind my suggesting that in my experience over a period of eighteen years in the North, the ideal plan for the bush Indian would be a "cottage" school for all the children during the Summer, and a continuation for picked pupils all winter while the parents were in camps. I would build a couple of cottages or a dormitory attached to the school under an elderly Indian caretaker. The brightest of the Summer pupils could be retained... (say a dozen) and in one winter I am sure more could be effected through them than in years of 'summer' educating... when the pupils go off in the Fall and come back next Summer having forgotten all they knew.

I do not advocate the Residential School as it is (among other things) too expensive and elaborate for the bush Indian. Such a 'cottage' school as I suggest could be operated by a married teacher or Missionary and the wife could teach the juniors and organise the women folk, etc. A good garden could be cultivated by the pupils, animals caught... all with the aid of the Indian caretaker... who might be an elderly couple.
I did not have time to discuss this with Bishop Rennison but he had invited me to fly into the missions this Summer as I have some knowledge of the Cree and Chipawayen. Unfortunately I cannot get away this year...but I am interested. I came out of the North because my two eldest children had to go on to higher education, but when we are through we intend returning.

I hope this will not seem an impertinence but in reading the reports from Ottawa and the Briefs presented I have yet to see anything as practical suggested for the North.

Sincerely

[Signature]

I note the arrangements as regard the teachers nominations and supplies for Mistassini & Waswanipi, rest assured the supplies will be delivered on time and I will be very pleased to assist the teachers.

The Chibougamau-Mistassini-Roberval road, is more in connection with huge pulpwood projects and power through the operators on the St-Maurice River down to Three Rivers, this year will be the last trip for the Mistassini Indians on Oskeneco, the best we hope for this season is to get some use out of the new road to as far as Chicobish Lake, about 90 miles by truck road and 90 miles by air on Mistassini towards late summer or early fall, however for 1949 it will be workable and dependable. I again recently discussed this matter with traders and operators of transports, for 1949 we should be able to realize a saving for the Indians and ourselves of about $25% to 33%, I am making a strong bid to get it this late summer on fall supplies, at least on Family Allowances.

The accommodations suggested for the Teachers at Mistassini & Waswanipi, are like last year, I consider unfair to the Teachers, and it does not create the desirable and badly needed example among these Indians more so at Mistassini. Cannon Mathew Shecapio is an Indian, family infected with T.B., Rev. Evans lived with them last year, I could never understand how they could do it. I regret to hear that Rev. Evans won't be at Mistassini this year, no doubt the main reason is living conditions experienced in 1947.

I note the arrangement for summer 1948, it is evident Mr. Higginson and Rev. Ellis understand the conditions they will have to put up with. I do hope that at Mistassini someone suitable does become interested in this work in a permanent way like, changing annually is viewed by the Indians, with a great deal of dislike and it follows they become non-interested. These Indians are better described as "sauvage" and it is only through an interested person returning for at least a number of years, that they will develop what we are all aiming at, no doubt after the new set-up is completed it will bring about the desired interest into the settlement.

This year Mistassini will be definitely free of ice by late May, if they wish to go in for June 1st, they will find a good number of Indians already in, they should be all there by the 15th. of June, the Nursing Station will be opened on June 7th.

Dear Colonel Neary,

I have waited for some time until I can give you a picture of our plans for the Indian schools this summer. I will take them in order.

(1). MISTASSINI. There are two teachers there. The Rev. C. Douglas Ellis, M.A. of Trinity College, Toronto and Arthur Higginson of 217 Fifth Avenue, Ottawa. They will fly in from Roberval on June 3 and will work together for about two months. I do not know if the new teachers' residence is finished but I have permission for them to use the old Hudson Bay Co. house in the meantime. With regard to this place I had a letter from the Rev. Condon about the possibility of sending a contingent of picked children from there to Moose Factory, by air. You will remember that two years ago 30 went to Chapleau and came back wonderfully improved. Although it seems remote, actually Moose Factory would be very suitable for these children. One large plane could carry about 20 and they would make the trip in three hours. I only want you to know that if the Indian school administration approaches you on the matter you have my consent.

(2). WASWANAPI. I understand that the school and the teachers' house are already completed. I am sending in Mr. P. J. Stephenson from Trinity College, Toronto, to take charge this summer. He will fly in from Senneterre about June 1st. He will be there until the end of September.

(3) LANSBOWE HOUSE on the Upper Albany River. Mr. R. E. Blight, B.A. of Huron College, London, will be flown in from Nakina at the end of the first week in June.

(4). FORT HOPE. Mr. R. W. Ross of Huron College, London, will go up with Mr. Blight and be flown in at the same time.

(5). COLLINS. You will remember that you approved of sending a man to do the work at Collins this summer. I have a man in sight, Mr. S. A. Ball, University of Toronto. He is a married man and has not seen his wife all winter. He would like to go if he can take her with him but $120 a month and his travelling expenses would
be required. I am not "holding you up" but would you tell me what you think of it? In the meantime I am putting Mr. Vollrick as the nominal teacher. I think it would be wise as an experiment this year, to see what he could do to shepherd the children there. I will send you further details later.

(6). OSNABURG INDIANS (Pickle Landing) The Rev. T. H. Bridle, B.A. You will remember during our conversation in April you told me that you would approve of the school being continued at Pickle Landing which is near Geraldton. Although it is only a rented building which we have improved for the present, you agreed that Mr. Bridle was a very capable person. Since then I have heard that Mr. Swartman has recommended that the school should be at Dog Hole where there is a medical centre. I agree that eventually if the government will build a school there it will be ideal but I am afraid they could not provide a building this year and if they did Mr. Bridle would not be able to give enough time and it is rather late to ensure a new man. I would ask your permission, for this year only, to allow the school to be continued at the landing. Give Mr. Bridle the grant and I know he will do a good job. For next year when there is a building and a man provided he will be very glad to hand it over to a summer teacher. May I ask you to wire me here before May 15th, if you approve of this as I will be seeing the missionary in charge at that time.

(7). GENERAL. I would like to tell you something about the financing of these schools, from our point of view. We are very grateful for the grants to the teachers. In the past, while they have not covered expenses, they have been reasonably adequate. But now, as you know, the cost of living in the north is very high. These students are putting themselves through college. I have found this year that I must guarantee to every man his travelling expenses both ways and $120 a month, as in the case of Mr. Ball, and we must advance their travelling expenses. These men vary in calibre but considering the character of the appointments I would be very glad if you would make the grants as high as possible, otherwise we may not be able to get men for another year and I am sure that until a permanent school is justified the present method is reasonably successful.

I am hoping to go to England for the Lambeth Conference in June and would like to have everything settled as soon as possible.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Col. Neary,

In my letter yesterday, I told you that I was going to write to you about the matter of our Summer Schools this year.

For your convenience, I will number them, and where necessary, make some observations.

1. Mistassini - This is the largest community, and you probably know all about it. I was there two years ago; owing to my trip to England, I could not make my Northern Journey last Summer. You were good enough to allow two men. I hope that the School and the Teachers' Residence are both completed by this time. You have already written me about the possibility of W. H. Thompson going there next Fall. This indicates that you are considering the possibility of having a man there for most of the year. There are six hundred people in the Summer. Would you consider sending two men this year, if I can find them?

2. Waswanipi - There, also, I hope that the new School and Residence are finished. I would like to know if that is the case, whether our Summer Teachers might have the use of the residence.

3. Lansdowne House - There are generally, two or three hundred Indians, coming and going, during the Summer. We have a church there and our own teacher's house.
4. Fort Hope - This is an old mission, where we had a man last year.

5. Collins - This place is on the Canadian National Railroad, a hundred miles West of Nakina. During the last three or four years, a great many Indians have come down for the Summer. They should be looked after and last year, we had a teacher there. These Indians are from the Northern Bands. We try to keep them from coming down the Railroad Line. There are many temptations there and the presence of a teacher seems desirable.

6. Pickle Landing - During the last two or three years, the Rev. T. H. Bridle of Central Patricia has done a remarkable work among the Indians at Dog Hole, Pickle Landing and also Osnaburgh. He is a trained teacher. I know that the Dept. has been thinking of finding some central place for a permanent school, but nothing has yet been decided. I am afraid, that this coming Summer, is the last one, when Mr. Bridle will be there. He deserves a larger sphere, but while he is there this Summer, I think, it would be a good thing if he were allowed to carry on. I know, that last Summer, with the help of an old car, he used to carry the children, several miles, in various directions, for his school.

7. Moose Factory Island - You will probably already have spoken to Mr. Clarke about the situation on Moose Factory Island. This is the site of the Indian Residential School, but there are many on the island in the Summertime, who are not pupils in the Residential School. I wonder, whether you would consider, having a student at Moose, this Summer, for the purpose of holding a Summer School. The other teachers are away for their holidays and I feel that an extra man could be valuable.
Col. B. F. Neary - 3.

This would make eight men, if you allow two for Mistassini.

I would like to know how many you think we should have for the coming Summer.

In the past, the Diocese has had to finance the travelling expenses and the monthly cheques for these men, until the Fall.

May I ask, whether you wish to continue this plan, in the future.

I would like to know, what salary the Dept. would be willing to pay this year.

To tell you the truth, we have had some difficulty in paying these students, and also paying their travelling expenses, which in most cases, includes transportation by airplane.

I am going to suggest, that it might be a good thing, if you could consult the Rev. Canon Cook of the Indian School Administration, 102 Bank Street, Ottawa, because he knows the details and the background of these schools. I will send him a copy of this letter.

I also hope that Mr. Clarke, who has just returned from Moose Factory, will be able to give you some light on the subject.

Every Summer, about the middle of June, I make a trip through all my Indian Missions, including James Bay and this year, I am going to Fort George and Whale River. We will finish at Mistassini. It seems incredible, but I can complete the trip, in about five weeks.
Col. B. F. Neary - 4.

I has occurred to me, that it might be a good thing, if the Dept. could see these schools in action, during the Summer. I therefore, asked Mr. Clarke, if he thought the Dept. would be interested in sending a man with me, this Summer, on my journey.

It might be a good investment, from the standpoint of gaining knowledge, and it would help both of us, for we could share the expense.

Yours faithfully,

I would much rather not have to take their cheques myself so that there will be no money transaction between us. If I have made any mistake in assuming that Mr. Brown has accepted you can let me know. I expect to begin my air journey about June 15th at Central Patricia, going down the Albany River, visiting about 6 posts and then around James Bay from Atawapiscut to Whale River and perhaps the Belcher Island then I will go Overland to Mistassini and Waswanapi, ending the journey at Val D'Or. It will be nearly 4,000 miles. I wish you could have sent one of your men with me, or come yourself.

Yours faithfully,
Sgd. Robert Moosonee.

There were over 600 Indians, all living in tents, there were two nurses looking after the sick, I found the school is almost finished and the teacher's residence will also be finished this fall. That will be a very great help, although in my opinion the school is a little small for the population. I found Mr. J. Schaffter, B.A. of Trinity College, Toronto, and Mr. Thomas Meikle, B.A. of Trinity College, Toronto, established in bachelors' quarters in the ruins of the old Hudson's Bay Co. house which was to have been demolished this summer but was spared at my request. It will not be needed next year.

I have always felt that when a school was completed and a teacher's residence built which should be consummated this fall I would like to speak to you about the possibility of putting in a resident teacher as a permanent missionary. As you know, perhaps, civilization is drawing near to this place. For 100 years it was separated entirely from the outside world. For the last 20 years it has been served by airplane from Roberval, but this has made transportation very expensive. The road is drawing near to the post. I believe that lumber companies have their eyes on the district. The lake itself is 150 miles long and 15 miles wide. My own opinion is that the Indians should be encouraged to hunt as long as possible. The lake is full of fish but they are mostly living, during the summer, on government rations and flour and lard. I think they are much healthier when they are living their nomadic life, but I am sure that we cannot stop this post having a population of 100 or so all the year round. I have heard rumours of an Indian boarding school there. I believe a government deputation went in but just as soon as Indians go to a boarding school for 5 or 6 years they cannot return to their tents and be happy and healthy.

Mr. Schaffter and Mr. Meikle have done admirable work. I advanced them $100 each before they left and they have charged up their purchases to me, for the present, besides that I paid $150 for their flight in to Mistassini and I suppose their return fare will be the same.
I received your letter, written during my absence, about their cheques which you sent to me. On my return I sent the cheques directly to them. Do you think in any way it would be possible to make some adjustment in order that they may be able to return at least part of the money which they have been advanced for travelling expenses?"

(Sgd.) Robert J. Renison
Bishop

Dear Colonel Neary,

I am enclosing a card addressed to Mr. R. Neil who is now living in British Columbia.

I would be very grateful if you would have your secretary insert his present address on the card and return it to us. He is a subscriber to Mrs. Renison's "Northland".

Christmas is now near, and the end of the year. I was very glad to hear that Mr. Allan of Moose Factory that he had at last been able to straighten out the report from our four teachers on James Bay. There was no difficulty anywhere, except with the returns of the Rev. Redfern Louttit of Old Factory River, who was able to produce a copy of his returns which had been forwarded to Archdeacon Clarke who found them.

Everything is now arranged for the future. The monthly salaries for each man are agreed upon but since the transition has taken so long there must be a comparatively large sum due to the Diocese. I would be very glad if you would send me these first returns for the past year or more, made payable to each man, as I will have to make an adjustment with them for money that we had to advance, pending the arrival of their cheques. After the adjustment is made I would like each monthly cheque, or quarterly if it is done that way, sent to each man at his address. I would much prefer that each man was responsible to the government for his own returns and that would be the best way to keep them up to the mark. It would be a great convenience if the back cheques could be sent before the end of the year.
I hope you will write me in good time, the date of your proposed trip to Moose Factory, as I should like to be at home when you arrive. We hope you will stay overnight at least. If possible I should like to go down with you.

With best wishes,

Yours faithfully,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir,

I have received Cheque No. 1791, for $80.00 dated March 23rd, 1920 in my favour for the credit of Charles Isenhoff, Teacher, Mistassini, Quebec, as bonus for July and August 1924. Should it not be $45.00?

I sent you his returns for the Dept. quarter 1924. These returns together with the receipts in receipt book and the account for rent shows clearly that he taught the school for September as well as July and August.

Will you kindly look into this and send me an explanation?

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

John G. Anderson
Bishop
Diocese of Moosonee

Cochrane, Ont.
Ottawa, March 30, 1925.

Right Reverend Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 25th instant, with reference to the payments made on the account of the Mistassini Indian Summer School.

In reply I beg to say that the return forwarded by the teacher, Mr. Charles Isenhoff, shows that the school was in operation for 35 days only during the September quarter. Under these circumstances the Department felt that payment for only two months could be allowed and a cheque for $150.00, covering the salary, was sent to the Royal Trust Company and a cheque for the bonus for two months was sent to you.

In the case of other schools in outlying districts which are only conducted for part of the year, the Department pays the salary of the teacher on a per ordinance basis. I believe that this would be the most satisfactory plan to follow with the Mistassini School. I consider that a rate of $4.00 for each day the school is actually in operation would be a fair amount to allow and I would be pleased to have your views regarding this suggestion.

I have the honour to be,

Right Reverend Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Rt. Rev. J. G. Anderson, D.D.,
Bishop of Moosonee,
Cochrane, ONT.

April 14th, 1925

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir,

Referring to your letter of March 30th last, I wish to say that I understand the fact that the returns showed only 35 days during which school was taught in the Dept. schools and therefore your explanation is quite satisfactory.

Regarding payment of $4.00 per day on a per attendance basis, I wish to call your attention to the fact that the district in which the Mistassini school is situated is very isolated and therefore somewhat different in the case of the schools I am referring to. However, I can agree with the proposal provided payment is allowed for holidays and sickness. Otherwise it would be a hardship that the teacher should lose its amount due for days of sickness and necessary holidays, as he must live whatever happens and provide for his needs.

Yours sincerely,

John G. Moosonee

Ottawa, April 7, 1937.

Right Reverend Sir:

The Department is in receipt of Your Lordship's letter of the 2nd instant, with reference to re-opening the Indian Day School at Mistassini. As this school has been closed for several years, no special provision has been made in our appropriation this year for the salary of a teacher. However, in view of your representations, we will favourably consider allowing the salary of a teacher for the summer months, only. The dates between which this school should be kept open might be June first to September 30th, provided the Indians would be close to Mistassini during that period.

For this summer school, we approve the appointment of George Iserhoff, and he will be allowed salary at the rate of $75.00 a month. At the end of the summer, the usual return forms should be completed and a report obtained, showing if the Indian parents sent their children to school regularly.

In the event of the school being a success this summer, the Department is inclined to favourably consider a year round school, if you believe that the attendance would warrant same. However, in this event, it would be necessary to secure a qualified teacher. In view of the number of qualified teachers at present unemployed, it is becoming increasingly difficult for the Department to consider paying salary to a teacher who has no teaching qualifications.

I have the honour to be,

Right Reverend Sir,

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Right Rev. John G. Anderson, D.D.,
Bishop of Moosonee,
Cochrane, Ont.
Ottawa, June 17th, 1937.

Right Reverend Sir,-

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 2nd instant and it is noted that George Laerhoff opened the Mistassini Indian Seasonal School on June 1st. He will be allowed salary at the rate mentioned in official letter of April 7th, 1937.

You did not mention in your letter to what address the register should be sent and, as this school has not been in operation for several years, the Department is not aware of the direct post office address. Under these circumstances, arrangements are being made to forward a register and some lead pencils to you. I trust you will be able to send them on to the school.

I have the honour to be,

Right Reverend Sir,-

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. H. Lariviere,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
A m o s, P. Q.

Mistassini Indian Day School

Mr. Arthur B. Higginson, of Carleton College, Ottawa, has been appointed as second teacher at the above Indian Day School. Mr. Higginson is an R.C.A.F. veteran, now in his third year at Carleton College. He is 27 years of age and is very keen to undertake the work which we are endeavouring to promote with the Mistassini Indians. He has discussed the local situation with both Bishop Renison and myself and has also written to the Reverend Mr. Ellis, who will be the senior teacher.

I understand that the Reverend Mr. Ellis may not stay the full term at Mistassini and that Mr. Higginson will probably finish the last two or three weeks out as the only teacher. I hope you will find his services satisfactory and that we can interest him in going in to Mistassini again next summer.

Bernard F. Heary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Ottawa, November 30, 1946.

Rental for Mistassini Indian Day School

Dear Bishop Renison:

Further to our interesting discussion of recent date, I have been checking the old files concerning the rentals paid in the past for various Anglican Churches used as part time Indian day schools. It is my intention to write you separate letters concerning each one.

I find that up to 1931 the following amounts were paid to Bishop Anderson for the use of the Church of England Church at Mistassini:

1. Allowance for scrubbing and sweeping during the months of June, July and August at $5 per month - $15.00

2. Rental of building used for school purposes during the above period - 3 months at $5.00 per month - $15.00

If it is necessary to run this school again during the next summer, the Department is prepared to make the same payments as previously arranged by us, in a letter sent to Bishop Anderson on June 21, 1924. Therefore it will be in order for you to submit accounts to this amount, quoting as authority our letter 44-9-5 of June 21, 1924.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Right Reverend R.J. Renison, M.A., D.D.,
Lord Bishop of Moosonee,
Bishopstope, Porcupine Highway,
Schumacher, Ontario.

The upstairs could be made into an apartment and the downstairs would make a fairly good school.

3. I am aware of the fact that there is a regulation that the Governments only build schools on a Reserve. This may be a good rule in certain settled places, but I am sure it could be modified in places where there is no reserve and the Indians have their only home for the summer.

4. One matter, which I was going to discuss with you more fully was taken over by Mr Phelan when we met in your office; for the sake of record I would like to put it in writing: In 1945 when Mr Burgomaster was at Mistisini he brought twenty-five children with him on his return. They were flown out to Oskelaneo which is 200 miles by air and from there they were taken by train to Chapleau; the distance by train alone must be nearly 500 miles. I thought that Mr Burgomaster had arranged with the Indian Agents; apparently he had to act quickly. I know that the regulations do not provide for the flying of children but a canoe trip in this case would have cost very much more besides incidental expenses for food I paid a bill to the Hudson's Bay Company for $350.00. The children all did well. This summer Mr Burgomaster brought out six children to Chapleau at a cost of $100. May I say that this summer the cheque for the school in Mistisini two months teaching was $217.00. Mr Burgomaster was very much more than a Teacher at the school. He was the guide philosopher and friend of 600 Indians. I am sorry he will not be with us next year. It would be a great encouragement to me when we can have a stable organisation at Mistisini. In the last two years during the summers our Mission has spent $2000.00 at Mistisini alone. I would be grateful if you and Mr Phelan can have this matter adjusted.

With kindest regards,

Yours faithfully,

Dear Colonel Neary,

1. I have six letters from you Nos. 72-7-1-72-2-5-44-1-5
   44-5-5-35-3-5 and
   35-12-5.

These deal with a situation of the schools which have been held
in our Indian Mission. I wish to say that I am obliged to you
for the interest and trouble which you have taken in considering
the relationship of the Church of the Indian Department over a
period of more than twenty years. I may say that my object in
discussing the matter was not to have the matter judged on the
basis of the Indian Department's actions and interest in schools
years ago. We all admit that times have changed and the claims
of the Indians have a new significance. Many of the nominal
grants which were authorised were never submitted. I would much
rather have the past record looked upon not as a standard for
present requirements but as a precedent for a forward policy
necessary today.

2. The most hopeful thing which I learned from our interview
was the promise to build a school and residence at Mistassini this
is the largest place and I hope will be merely the beginning. If
I can have a definite assurance that this can be undertaken next
summer before April 1st, we can undertake plans. I would prefer
that the Department erected the buildings but if necessary I would
be willing to try to have it done by private contract which could
use local labour. The next year we should do the same at Waswanipi.
As a matter of fact, we have two buildings there one is the Church
which needs restoration and it has been used for a school for twenty
five years. There is a residence for the teacher or Missionary which
needs an expenditure of $500 to put it in repair. I would be willing
to give this building to the Department for a school and summer resi-
dence for the Teacher if they would undertake to have it restored.

" 500 Poles for making fences - length about 16 to 20 feet top 2 inches Price in the bush $.10 cents each.

The removing from the bush, peeling towing and piling we will pay separately.

In spring all logs 800 16 feet or 18 feet, should be piled, in the narrows at point, where I said last year, it would be an ideal spot for a "saw pit", all these logs, will cut in halves like we did for the nursing station.

All the others to be piled at about where Willie Jimikin and the Trappers had their camp, last summer.

You may put on this job any of the Indians around the Post, including the women if they wish to cut poles and the smaller logs. March 4th, 1947

Dear Mr. McLeod:

I have yours of the 28th. of February 1947, I wrote you on February 27th, as regard logs for proposed school, gave quantities and sizes. It is noted the two best "saw pit men" are around, there is no objections that they go ahead and start sawing as soon as delivered to the Post.

If they want to, they can go ahead and make boards, with the best logs 16' (feet) 1." I presume in what they will make "mark every two inches and saw off on the mark", the 16' foot logs, they should sawed in halves, like we did for the nursing station, price as paid last year $.40 per cut is satisfactory.

The price delivered quoted, is about what I figured they would cost, better fix the price for cutting separately and if the same man complete and deliver it is O.K. "pay after the work is done".

As regard the fuel wood for the Nursing Station, I am aware the shed is full of good wood now, but I want to have enough to fill the shed in fall 1947, for 1948, I have no objections that they cut, B.L.C.H., off the ridge at $5.00 per cord delivered, piled, etc., as usual.

If you get the logs cut, on the south side of the lake, likely they will be larger in diameter this is O.K. If you can get some nice spruce logs over 40 feet, we could take about 10 of them, naturally we would have to pay more for them - 1 piece - it will be O.K. also.

The main point, is to keep them working instead of loafing and waiting, for relief or "Family Allowances" and that they get sick, considering the scarcity of country food, etc., will do the final adjustment in June.

In reply the name of the school is Mistassini, if we take into account, the supplies that had to go in on account MEDICAL being very bulky and the size of aircrafts at disposal at various bases, we could not handle the bulky goods any other way and to complete load, we had nothing heavy enough to fill in allowed capacity on this trip, except by shipping new roofing paper that we will need for school in 1948, briefly it is a combined trip and in some ways the MEDICAL is getting the benefit of it, but often it works out the contrary, in this case they were charged the same price for "their bulky supplies", had we shipped these through Roberval, I estimate the Pilot would have carried the bulky supplies, and likely charge us the "minimum trip load" with a lesser weight and would have worked out in this case to a much higher per pound rate.

My experience on combined trips like we have, or can make up at times, the route used like in this case is the last outlet.

The weight of paper "extra heavy" shipped on account at Mistassini, ordinary roofing won't stand up, high wind and even when ordinary paper is used and loaded it won't give satisfaction.

The rates for that area are high, however during the course of present summer, the rates will go up, for the franchise are cancelled I understand and this means higher still, the canoe route allows only barged goods, within safety and if one figures the spoilage it works out to "air rate".

January 26th, 1949.

To The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

Att'n Mr. B. F. Neary, Supt. Education

Further to our conversation when in Ottawa last, since I have prepared slowly to cover completion of Obedjiwan, Manowan and Mistassini schools.

Mr. Magnus Edwardson, who has been doing work for us on nursing stations and schools, is prepared to go in with others and do all this work this summer.

Considering, it is absolutely impossible to make arrangements for crews of men, their transportation, also supplies, at the last minute; and to do these three jobs this summer it means rushing in immediately after break up and if possible before, that is last trips. I would appreciate authority to make arrangements to do this work on account season 1949-50.

As regard Waswanipi, it is only a matter of a man going in for about a month to complete details. Here, there is a plan underway to do some Indian houses, in any event some improvements. I estimate completion of the school will be possible probably through these other men, which means savings on transportation, etc.

Requisitions for supplies are being prepared now and I hope to be able to submit by early February for spring delivery if you have funds available on present fiscal year, or for early summer delivery as a charge to 1949-50 appropriations. Our summer program is developing to a new high, that is very heavy, and if we experience too many delays we won't be able to carry it out. Our medical service alone calls for 6 to 7 nurses in the field. Here as you know everything has to be worked out in full details to put it over. This with other things we have only 3 or 4 months to do it. Needless to say we must be prepared in advance and everything must be timed well ahead.

(Sgd) H. Lariviere, Supt.

Conied: V.S.

Some of these supplies, depending on what arrangement I can make, etc., will endeavour to secure in Lake St-John - Roberval, for shipment by road.

As regard men to do this work, it is important that arrangement be made in very near future or else these men will go on other jobs. I depend a great deal on the men employed by us in the past, mainly the Edwardson at Oskelaneo.

If it is your intention that we go ahead and finish Mistassini this summer, all must be prepared now and delivered at Oskelaneo for June 1st. or else, I regret we cannot handle it, at a figure near what we estimated when this matter was first discussed with Mr. Neary.

To The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

Attention: Mr. J.E. Gendron, R.S. for P. of C.

Further to conversation, your last visit at Amos, we have received no information, as to if it is desired that this job be completed this summer.

Here it is extremely important that if we are going to go ahead with, that material etc., be all on hand at Oskelaneo River, Que., for June 1st, we could very likely handle most of, on part loads, return flights, on Agency general usual services, next arrangements for men to go in etc., must be done before May 15th, otherwise it is next best to impossible to handle this job, at a price "normal figure".

If this work is not going to be done this year, logs, piled, peeled in 1947, must be disposed of, or most of them will be spoiled. If job cannot be done early this summer, I would appreciate authority to use logs, for making "Indian tent frames".

Men to hire:
- Mr. Angus Edwardson - foreman
- Mr. Lawrence Edwardson - axe man
- Mr. ?? Edwardson p axe man and general
  (son of Angus about 23)

at a rate of pay of $7.00 for foreman, $6.00 for others, transportation and food, from date of departure to date of return, shelter tents. These are the going rates of pay, for bushmen, employed by mining companies and others for this class of work.

Would like to have these men go in, first or second trip after ice is clear at Mistassini. If other supplies are not delayed with the help of the Indians, this job should be finished by early August, subject to weather and usual, in any event when Nurse will be ready to come out in August, the job should be closed, if necessary completed in 1950, unless we are assured of transportation out, on a returning flight.

I expect to be able to land at Mistassini anytime after the 15th., I would appreciate authorization by wire.

H. Lariviere - Supt. Indian Agency.

Your letter File No. 321-4 (E1)
November 12th, 1949

I note the decision, on our Requisition for "Key Tags with hooks".

With the old schools, endless troubles were caused with keys going astray, however the buildings were not altogether our responsibility. With the new schools, it doesn't adjust the key troubles, we will have the same difficulties, which are almost anything that can happen to a key or keys. A pet habit when keys do go astray, they brake a glass to get in and so, or use a steel bar or an axe to open doors. On our new MEX schools if they do this, it means smashing our doors.

We tried various methods to control keys on Nursing Stations, which is just as bad as on schools, we failed to get success, we had tags - wooden, made by Indians, with strings, the wooden tags "rub off" the "strings cut off", we had them on a wire loop, they take them off one by one, finally, we find keys with Indians, traders and so on.

I estimated a regular "Hotel Key Tag" with the usual strong hook, would adjust, all these keys be given a number "stamped" (we have the stamping punches) registered at Agency, and whoever is entitled to have these keys, be held responsible, between the schools and the nursing stations, we have a very large number of keys. With a good control we should get results.

The regular MASONITE KEY TAG WITH HOOKS, I feel would adjust and would be cheaper, an Indian during a day does not whittle many "sticks" in a day, using sticks we do not overcome, pencil marking rubbing off and cutting of strings.

H. Lavriere - Supt. Indian Agency.

Replying yours, calling our attention to what appears to be a change by us on Purchase Orders, on one of the P.O. it was noted by the Purchasing Agent, extra $1.75 for copper screen wire fine mesh.

As far we were concerned here, we were satisfied that this supplier had the same difficulties on screen wire, like others, going over the copies of P.O., we noticed the note by the Purchasing Agent, $1.75 extra for copper, so we took for granted, it was understood, if necessary applicable to all.

Re: Mistassini Indian Day School

On reviewing our books, we find that the following expenditures have been made at the above school:

Fiscal year 1947-48 - $4,345.90
" " 1948-49 - 151.55

In the appropriation for the current fiscal year, we provided an amount of $6,000.00 for expenditures at this school, and you will note that this amount has been expended with the exception of $22.00.

It will, therefore, be necessary for us to transfer funds from another project, due to the fact that the following Vouchers have not yet been paid:

Voucher #20 - $161.00
" #1131 - 161.10

Ottawa, April 3, 1925.

Reverend Sir:

Pursuant to our conversation of this morning, I wish to state that the Department will assist you in your activity among the Indians at Obedjiwan, on the St. Maurice River, Que. (60 miles north of Oscalanea). I understand it is your purpose to conduct a summer school during the months of June to September inclusive, and I will agree to the appointment of two teachers—one for classroom activity and the other for field matron's duties in Indian homes. Salaries of $75 and $50 per month, supplemented by any bonus provided by law, will be allowed.

This Department will also arrange for certain school room supplies:

- 20 Readers, Dom. Catholic, Part I (French edition)
- 30 Slates (medium)
- 3 Boxes Slate Pencils
- 2 Boxes White Chalk
- 1 Beaver plate Blackboard 12 ft. x 3½ ft.
- 3 Blackboard brushes
- 1 Numeral frame
- 2 Dozen Scribblers
- 6 Dozen Lead Pencils
- 2 Pkts. Ink powder
- 1 Box Pens
- 6 Sheets blotting paper
- School Register and Quarterly Return forms.

This equipment, with the exception of the 30 slates, will be ordered through the Government Stationery Office and shipped to you at Oscalanea, in care of Mr. John Midgley. You are authorized to purchase the slates and submit the bill, in duplicate, properly certified by yourself, to the Department.

I should be pleased to have an answering communication, informing us of your wish to proceed with the work and intimating the names and qualifications of the teachers that you engage.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy Secretary.

Ottawa, March 12th, 1924.

Rev. Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 10th instant, regarding the opening of a summer school at Obedjiwan for the months of June, July, August and September.

In reply I beg to say it is noted that you are endeavouring to obtain the services of two teachers—one for classroom activity and the other for the matron's duties in the Indian homes. If you can obtain suitable teachers for the above services, the Department will provide salary and bonus at the rate of $50 per month to the teacher and $65 per month to the matron. Kindly inform the Department, as soon as you are in a position to do so, of the names, qualifications and experience of the teachers engaged by you.

We are placing an order with the Government Stationery Office to ship addressed to you in care of Mr. John Mcle, c., Oskelino, G.N.R. (Transcontinental Ry.), the school supplies mentioned in our letter of April 3, 1923.

We note that you will purchase and have forwarded the 50 slates. You should obtain accounts, in duplicate, and you should certify thereon that the slates were received by you and that the prices charged are fair and just. When these accounts have been received at the Department, payment will be made.

A daily register, for keeping the attendance of the pupils, and a supply of forms to be used by the teachers in preparing their returns, will be sent you under separate cover, which please hand to the teachers whom you engage.

We hope that you will be successful in obtaining the services of suitable teachers in time to begin duties as early in June, next, as possible.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.
