Dear Aunt Gertrude,

I will find in this envelope two or three letters from the Department of Public Printing. I have signed them.

The school teacher left us yesterday, a person of experience and a good house keeper. She came here by ship on June 15th and finished the journey by train. Her name is Madame Jean De Laire, Escalante, Chile.

June. My address is Miss Alexandra Belean, Assiniboia (Manitoba), Que. — Hope you will not delay to pay Madame Lea De Lain and Miss Alexandra Belean.

I am looking for an other Matron teacher. I will advise as soon as possible the qualification and experience of the person engaged by me, and also I will state the date on which she will commence her classes.

I could not write to the Department before this date, being away giving missions and not knowing yet whether the teachers were on duty or not.

We have received the statement from Librarian Langlois. We have signed the account.

We are building a fine school and a house for the teachers of the prairie.

Yours truly,

Mr. J. D. McLean,

Sir:

Through the Reverend Father Guinard, O.M.I., you have requested a summary report of the services rendered and the work done at the Domestic Science School of Obiduan.

During the month of June we have occupied our time with sewing. The Indian women who have returned from the bush had several dresses to cut and sew for themselves and their children.

The cleaning and ironing of the men's clothes took a good part of the time. I also occupied myself with the fixing up of their homes which for the major part were in great disorder.

I must say that until now I did not have the advantages nor a suitable place to work.

It is with great pleasure that we are taking possession this week of a nice large school with a stove, tables, benches, etc. I intend to divide my time to teach the principal matters regarding the care and work of the house.

I even intend to teach them for a change and as a recreation how to embroider and to make lace work. The Indian girls are very intelligent and some of them appear to be quite clever.

I will teach until the first of October according to my engagement.

I have to honour to be,

Sir,

your humble servant.

Elida Brosseau

Sir:

I take it to be my duty to send you a report for the first month of teaching at the school of Obiduan, County of Champlain, Quebec. Having not yet received special forms for my report, I am doing so in the best way possible on this sheet.

The school is open since the first of June. It will close on the first of October.

The number of pupils inscribed on the register is forty-five (45), nineteen (19) girls and twenty-six (26) boys.

Average attendance of the girls seventeen (17), the average attendance of the boys at school sixteen (16). Number of school days during the month of June, twenty-one (21).

The attendance of the boys at school was upset during this month as they were occupied transporting the stores of the Hudson Bay Company on the Indian Reserve. The number of pupils registered is inferior to that of last year, as many of them go now to the school of Waymontachinque.

The class room is large and clean, well lighted and well furnished; but to favour the progress of our good little Indians a few articles are missing yet, such as daily copy books, writing books, series, one, two and three, ink stands, maps of Canada.

I wish to ask for all these as they are quite necessary.

Yours, etc.,

A. Bibeau.
Teacher.

Madam:

The assistant teacher should also furnish a brief statement at the end of each month showing the work she performed in teaching the children sewing, etc., and any work that she has done in the Indian homes.

September 12, 1931.

Mr. A. F. MacKenzie, Secretary,
Ottawa.

Sir,

Very conscientiously, I come to give you the reasons of my early departure from the mission of Obidjuan. The Reverend Father Guenard had fixed the date on the 17th I had therefore only three school days left. Kindly remark that I was keeping the class every Saturday to leave the mission sooner. I was so much run down that I was unable to teach. I judged that it was better for me to return home. The appointment I received was to teach at Osekelaneo, and I was greatly disappointed when I had to go to Obidjuan. I did not lose courage in front of such sacrifice. I found that the work was great and I felt happy with my Indian scholars. The work was very hard, but I kept it up as much as I could and when I saw my health vanishing I abandoned it.

I hope that you will be kind enough to send me my full salary at Ste. Theodosie.

Yours devotedly,

(Sgd.) Mrs. Felix Larose, Teacher.

Ste. Theodosie,
County of Vercheres.
Quebec.

Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Gentlemen,

From September 1st to September 23, I made a daily visit to all the Indians on the Reserve. I attended several sick persons, especially five or six youngsters who were hysterical. This disease became almost an epidemic.

Everything is normal now and the youngsters are better, except one whom I thought best to bring to the doctor at Clova, as the party in question was in no condition to leave for the woods.

I spent several hours of the day teaching sewing and the Indian girls have done better work this year than last year.

With the material sent me I was able to make dresses, coats, and shirts for 52 children. However, the quantity was not sufficient as there are approximately 30 little Indians for whom I could sew if I had some more.

Will you please send me my salary cheque to the following address.

To Mr. Phelan, Sup. of Ind. Schools,

Sir:

Last evening, I received a letter from Miss Alice Hubert, the one that visited you last Friday; and taught in Obedjiwan last summer. She told me: I was very well received. Miss Alice Hubert is the best school teacher of my missions. She worked very hard, she had in her class about eighty (80) pupils. Miss Alice Hubert is well liked by the Indians.

Last summer, when I saw her, she told me that she was teaching every Saturday; I advised her to continue and give the number of school days lost.

You know that she could not be in Obedjiwan in time, the lake was covered with ice.

Sir, probably you do not know that Miss Alice Hubert is a nurse too. She treated with success bad cases and even hospital cases. By this she saved money to the Department and too likely she will save some again if she return in Obedjiwan.

Now I will be pleased if you allow me to re-engage Miss Alice Hubert.

Your truly servant in X.

To The Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

Re : Obijuan Indian Summer Day School Teachers

Herewith returns for June & July 1943, I have visited Obijuan in early July and again on August 22/23rd., as regard Miss. Madeleine Julien, I consider this person 100% unfit for our work at a Summer Day School.

1.- Being the 1st. Teacher, made it very difficult for her assistants. On my arrival in July, I found that Miss. Tremblay had been more or less nothing for a servant girl.

2.- There was no work done, for the time put in, I was presented with a long serial of various troubles, needs for improving the Teachers House, etc., regularly.

3.- Miss. Julien, being a person employed to go out lecturing, organize meetings, door to door cells, in view to combat certain social difficulties, etc., remedy all ills, lack the main quality to promote our interests among these Indians, this quality is common ordinary sense.

4.- I spoke to the Chief, who is an ordinary Indian but intelligent, his reference as to her ability - "too high class for us ordinary people".

5.- On the school garden, her direction to promote this part, I am of the opinion an ordinary Indian could have done better, on all matters of interest to us, excuses and finally she admits she knows very little along our needs, but will learn during coming winter for next year, etc., her views and actions, having not changed since July, at which time both were fully explained what was desired, I recommend as follows:

That Miss Madeleine be refused to teach any of the Indian Summer Day Schools, at least in this Agency.

On clothing, it is evident she had in mind to make a show, I was showed a large wooden box over filled, with practically nothing in it, only a few Indian made articles on top. The excuse was they no military clothing, I showed in the storage a very large quantity and good assortment waiting for willing hands to work.

H. Lelièvre - Indian Agent.

Pour la question de pension, ceci est une cause de troubles, d'ailleurs les institutrices trouvent déjà le travail assez difficile et tous les ans, sur cette affaire nous avons des plaintes, à Manouan tout particulièrement durant deux ans, les institutrices n'ont pas donné le rendement possible à cause des pensionnaires, cette année nous désirons établir un service de garde-malade à Obedjiwan Manouan et Weymontachie, en coopération avec les écoles et si possible la garde devra demeurer avec elles, durant son séjour sur les Réserves, naturellement nous ferons une allocation généreuse. En dehors de notre service je ne puis pas intervenir, d'ailleurs je suis contre le principe que les institutrices devraient les gens à titre de maison de pension.

Je comprends l'embêtement dans votre cas surtout cette année à Obedjiwan, je crois que si vous étiez capable de trouver une personne convenable, Mr. Boone serait satisfait de faire des arrangements pour la pension des frères, un autre moyen serait que durant la construction qu'ils prennent une maison et s'organisent, Véronique Dubé devrait être capable de leur faire la cuisine etc., Véronique comme cuisinière en dehors de l'école, je crois serait la meilleure solution.

Pour la question de l'eau à Obedjiwan, si nous pouvons, c'est l'intention de faire faire des puits, naturellement nos hommes seront forcément obligés de faire comme les autres, leurs propres arrangements pour pension et ceci en dehors de l'école.

Reverend Father:

I have received your letter of the 30th of January. In regard to Obedjiwan, I note that you are of my opinion re Miss Agathe Gagne, and that I am of yours re Miss Ganim. Let us hope that she finds a companion.

In regard to the board, I may say that this is a cause of worry. The teachers find the work very difficult and we received complaints every year in this connection, and especially at Manouan for the past two years, where the teachers did not give satisfactory services because there were boarders there. We intend to establish this year a nursing service at Obedjiwan, Manouan and Weymontachie, which will work in cooperation with the schools and, if possible, the nurse could share the teachers' house while on the reserves. Naturally we will grant generous allowance. I cannot intervene in affairs not connected with our service, and I am opposed to the principle that the teachers should act as boarding-house keepers.

I am aware of your embarrassing situation at Obedjiwan this year. I believe that if you could find a responsible person, Mr. Boone would be satisfied with the arrangements in regard to the Brothers' board. As an alternative they could rent a house and organize themselves during the construction. Veronique Dube should be able to act as cook, and the best solution would be that she attends to her work outside the school.

In regard to the water situation at Obedjiwan, we intend to dig a well there. Naturally our men will have to do like the others, that is room and board outside the school.

Please be assured of my full cooperation when at all possible, and I extend to you the Season's Greetings.

Yours very truly,

(S.) H. Lariviere, Indian Agent.
À Monsieur Hervé Larivière,

monsieur;

Les Fêtes sont passées, puisque nous voilà à la fin de janvier. Comme d'habitude, je suis allé à Weymontaching pour la Noël, puis à Obedjiwan pour le 1er de l'An avec notre Paul Megweto, enfin à la Loutre pour l'Epiphanie.

Je n'ai pas oublié de prier et pour vous-même et pour votre honorable famille. Bien entendu, si Amos était sur mon chemin, de tout cœur j'arrêterais vous voir, vos chers petits surtout. Comme déjà ça doit grandir.

Pour les institutrices de 1945, c'est toujours Obedjiwan depuis nombre d'années qui ne cessent de subir des changements. Je crois bien faire à ne pas proposer le nom de Melle Agathe Garné. L'année dernière, elle n'a pas donné satisfaction suffisante, puis son caractère difficilement s'accorde avec celui de Melle Annette Ganim. Je crois que Melle Annette Ganim sera meilleure institutrice. J'ai reçu de Soeur Agnès un certificat à son sujet. Je vous l'envoie. Sous peu, je vais savoir de Melle Annette Ganim quelle demoiselle qui pourrait être seconde avec les qualités requises à cet effet et avec laquelle ensemble il y aurait "bon ménage".

Pour les travaux dans nos missions, disons que Manawan et Weymontaching sont finis; il ne reste plus qu'Obedjiwan. La Chapelle est trop petite et il faut la rafraîchir. C'est même, il me semble, une question d'hygiène et donc de santé. Pour la dernière fois, j'ai obtenu d'avoir encore le Frère A. Sauvé, o.m.i. Comme alors, il faut hâter les travaux, j'espère avoir un deuxième Frère oblat. Il reste à prévoir la question de pension. J'avais pensé que la H.B.C. pourrait le faire, mais après information auprès de M. Bone et de M. Watson, ils objectent qu'il n'y a pas moyen facilement pour eux de
trouver une cuisinière à Obedjiwan et qu'alors M. Bone se fait à lui-même sa cuisine, etc.

Alors, j'ai pensé que puisque c'est aussi l'avantage du Département que la Chapelle soit hygiénique en l'agrandissant, qu'alors nos institutrices pourraient les nourrir comme par le passé, quitte assurément compensation suffisante pour la dépense, mais craignant un surcroît de travail pour les institutrices, je recours à vous et je sais que si vous le voulez vous pouvez arranger cela en ce sens que vous pourriez gratifier nos institutrices, pour cet été, du 1er juin au 15 septembre, d'une aide c.à.d. d'une femme ou fille pour le travail de leur maison, cuisson des aliments et entretien, etc., et vu que la question de l'eau à Obedjiwan est vraiment difficile, vu la distance, vous pourriez mettre un homme qui tous les jours fournirait l'eau nécessaire. Ainsi, tout serait réglé et cela grâce à votre coopération.

Veuillez me croire votre tout dévoué,

Ed. Meilleur, o.m.i.

Dear Sir:

The holidays are over as we have reached the end of January. I have visited Weymontaching at Christmas as usual, Obedjiwan on New Years Day with Paul Megwetc, and la loutre on little Christmas.

I have prayed for you and for your family. If Amos was on my way, I would certainly visit you.

In regard to the teachers for 1945, those appointed to Obedjiwan have been changed very often. I think I am right in not proposing Miss Agathe Gagne's name. Her services were not satisfactory last year and Miss Annette Ganim and her could not agree. I believe that Miss Annette Ganim will be a better teacher. I have received from Sister Agnes a certificate about her. I will know soon from Miss Annette Ganim the name of a young woman who would have the necessary qualifications to assist her and with whom she could agree.

In regard to the work done in our missions, we are through at Manawan and Weymontaching; there remains but Obedjiwan. The chapel is too small there and it must be re-decorated. It is even a question of hygiene and health. Brother A. Sauve, C.M.I. has been appointed here for the last time. As the work must be rushed, I hope to obtain the services of another Oblate brother. We must foresee the question of their board. I have thought that the Hudson Bay Company could do it; after receipt of information from Messrs. Bone and Watson, they are of the opinion that it is quite difficult to secure the services of a cook at Obedjiwan, and Mr. Bone is his own cook. As it would be in the Department's interest that a larger chapel be more hygienic, our teachers could feed those gentlemen as in the past, provided, naturally, that they receive sufficient compensation. As more work would have to be done, I take the liberty of asking you to find out if our teachers could be given some help this Summer, between June 1st and September 15th. A girl or a woman could provide for the upkeep of the house, cook the meals, etc. As the water problem exists at Obedjiwan, in view of the distance, maybe a man could be appointed to supply it daily. Thus, everything would be settled, thanks to your cooperation.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd.) Ed. Meilleur, C.M.I.

Ottawa, June 23, 1945.

Mr. H. Lariviere, Indian Agent,
Amos, Que.

I desire to refer to my letter of February 14, 1945, with reference to the teachers at the seasonal schools providing meals for casual visitors.

Recently, I was forwarded a copy of the notice which you issued to the teachers. If your notice is interpreted literally it would mean that the teachers would be forbidden to serve meals to the Bishop or any clergyman when their occasional visits are made. It was never my intention to prohibit the serving of meals to people such as those just mentioned.

I took the impression from your letter of February 2 that white people, travelling through the country on business of their own, were bothering the teachers by requesting them to serve them meals.

I trust that you will adjust the matter in a manner satisfactory to all parties concerned. It is not a subject on which there should be any great divergence of views and certainly should be settled without bothering this office and without causing any undue hardship.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
To The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

Your Letter No. 69-3-1 June 23rd, 1945

I acknowledge yours of the 23rd. ult., as regard the interpretation, the teachers are familiar with the need and it was never understood by my knowledge by them or intended to deprive any members of the clergy on official visit to Indians.

But the teachers do understand that young priests travelling in groups or two or three, as tourists are not official members of the clergy within the meaning of servicing Indians, this class should be considered as "whites", the teachers are familiar that restrictions does not cover, such as if they desire to invite them, etc., they cannot do so, them or others.

I am most anxious that all concerned do not take advantage of the teachers and that they don't take advantage of others, reports that have reached me so far this summer do indicate that the teachers troubles are fairly well adjusted.

I doubt that any other persons except Rev. Meilleur would feel offended by placing the teachers to protect themselves on abuses that some one might try to impose on them when visiting these Reserves.

I will visit these Reserves in near future if there is anything to adjust it will be looked into. At Manouan one summer the Teachers experienced very little left off their wages, due to feeding all visitors,

H. Lariviere - Indian Agent.

I submit the following report:-

OBEDJIWAN INDIAN RESERVE

One difficulty was met the SCHOOL, this year, nothing was done on remodelling clothing, etc., this mainly due to the fact, the building used for that purpose the property of the Indians, maintained by us, had been used by the Mission to store building material for alterations to the church, etc., I also found that the TEACHER had registered only the children of school age, who came to the school, they like elsewhere were furnished with a complete list of the Band, on going over I found only about 50% of the children had reported, also a great percentage was not attending regularly, further a certain number classed grade 3 and 4 in my opinion they could be classed all grade 1 regardless of age. The Register is being adjusted to show all children of school age, etc., the attendance on this basis in July will be about 18/20%.

The school building, is far too small to take care of children, considering this instead of allowing them relief for clearing land, I arranged with the Chief that the destitutes Indians cut and deliver, about 200 logs during summer months, the price was fixed $1.10 delivered, for logs spruce NOTHING UNDER 21" top 8", piled on skids, with these logs on hand, a good building could be put up for our purposes, any time later and at no extra cost. The School Teachers' house, requires painting, exterior and interior, also certain repairs this will be attended to later, for 1946, Urgent immediate needs were provided for during visit.

In reply, I must say that their remark over Indians don't travel at night, it is contrary to their habit; they cross the lakes most of the time at nights and further most of my trips in that area, were made particularly on return during late evenings and nights.

The main reason for going out in the first place and being overdue it was a question of attending a party at Senneterre and Miss. July 5th, 1948

To The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

Your letter No. 74-9-1 (El) June 22, 1948.

I acknowledge receipt of yours dated June 22nd, granting leave of absence to the Obedjiwan Day School teachers for the purpose to go home to vote in the Provincial elections.

On my arrival at Amos from Mistassini I made inquiries I find any person employed away from home may register at any polling stations before July 18th and they will be able to vote in the district in which they are living. In the case of the Obedjiwan teachers, it is Oskelaneo. Further I understand the various government services in this case Fire Protective Association will assist on transportation of voters in remote areas.

I suggest that these teachers be advised to register at Oskelaneo polling station. It will save them considerable money on travelling expenses and they should be absent from the school not over two days.

As regard other points, field staff I understand is already aware of the routine to follow. Menowen can vote at Casey, Weymontachie can vote at Sammar.

In order to avoid any possible friction I am communicating with members of the field staff and making them aware of the routine to follow.

H. Lariviere - Superintendent Ind. Agency.

Maniwaki October 17, 1938

Department of Indian affairs
Ottawa, Ont.

Gentlemen;

I am writing to you regarding the balance on my salary for to date I have received the sum of $225.00 on the $260.00 due to me. As I am in need of money and not working would you be good enough to send me same at once.

You must understand that the salary for the hardship we get is small enough added to the expenses we have to reach and return from there more over having no work when we get back, that we are in need and can not afford to wait for same.

Hoping to hear from you by return mail in a favorable way, I remain.

Yours truly,

Juliette Lafrance
Montreal. November the 9th, 1938

Mr. J. R. L. Macdonald, Sec.
Department of Indian Affairs.
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir,

If I remember well, I have asked in my last Report to send the balance of my salary to the "Banque Canadienne Nat. on Rideau St."

When I left Ottawa, on the 31st of October, the salary of the last fifteen days (from the 15th to the 31st of September) was not in yet. I wonder if that last check has been sent to Obijuan But where I taught last summer or if it is only a delay in the payment.

As I will be back in Ottawa only on the 1st of January, I would be very much obliged to you if you could advise me as soon as possible.

I remain,

Alice Hubert, A.G.M.

Juliette Lafrance

Senneterre, Nov. 9, 1947.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

On October 28 I wrote you in connection with a cheque in the amount of $62.50 which was owing to me for my services as teacher at the Obedjiwan Indian reservation. I received no news about this matter and I did not receive the cheque. Please note that this amount is owing to me for the work done from the 1st to the 15th of September which means that almost two months have elapsed since I left the Indian reserve. I suppose that there has been an oversight and that I shall soon receive this salary cheque. I have been out of work since the closing of the schools and this money would be very useful to me as I am the support of my father and mother and with the cost of living as high as it is today, it is hard to get along without any money.

I trust that my request will be taken into consideration.

Yours truly,

Lorette Ganin,
Senneterre,
Abitibi, P.Q.

Dear Sir,

Obijuan Indian Band - School

At this point, the Indians provided the Band with one vacant house (18' x 24') for a school, that is a second school. On August no date, the Missionary wrote and demanded, that we furnished certain material to complete, as follows:

14 Sheets Ten-Test 4'x6' ½"
Paint for the interior (Surface - height given only 9')
Lumber in sufficient quantity to build the teacher's desk and for 40 children.

This building as an Indian house, is fairly good, the roof requires roofing cement; the reason why they demand Ten-Test they started to line it with this material.

My recommendation is, if the Department is in a position to consider, that they be allowed the following:

14 Sheets Ten-Test 4'x6' ½"
1 G. Floor Paint - Enamel Color Grey. Dark
1 G. Wall sizing
5 Lbs. Glue (for water mixing as a filler)
1 G. Interior paint - white
1 G. Boiled Linseed Oil (double boiled)
1 Only Paint Brush 4" flat - cheap.
2 G. Exterior Paint - grey
1 G. Linseed Oil - boiled
4 G. Roofing Cement ½ Gall. Tins.

March 18th, 1948

To The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

Your No. 74-9-5, 74-12-5, & 74-7-5 (E1)
March 15th, 1948

Re: Hair Clippers & Barber's Shears for SUMMER DAY SCHOOLS

During recent visit to all hospitals where we have Indians, going over FIELD NOTES 1947, demands from Teachers and reasons by Indians for not complying with demands, by Nurses and self, I found it necessary to order this equipment for these Summer Day School- Camps.

Most of the Indian children are full of head lice, causing IMPETIGO, this form of disease is contagious, it causes among them infected sores and finally a number of cases have to be hospitalized, our hospitalization cost on infected common sores through impetigo and impetigo itself is very high, I dare say with an effort from the part of the Teachers, guidance by nurses, this can be wiped out the starting point I firmly believe is HAIR CUTTING, as they enter the schools, once they will develop the habit they will keep it up on this like other matters, which gives them some form of relief.

I placed the requisitions with you under HEADING OF SCHOOLS, for I feel the TEACHERS can best look after that part, considering the EDUCATION DIVISION cannot supply, I presume the matter should be referred to WELFARE OR MEDICAL. Further much clothing over impetigo has to be destroyed, outside of creating pressure on them to wash, bedding and so on.

Last year Nurse Drouin, did cut hair, to a great number of children, to treat a number of Indian children, I do not see that a nurse should spend time on hair cutting, if we had suitable equipment at the SCHOOLS the teachers could go the houses and demand that they do these things themselves, in lot of cases of infected impetigo I had to interfere myself to get the hair cutting done to clean it.

.............. over
I am much interested, to overcome infected sores, soaks, and impetigo and sending to hospitals Indian children for type of treatment.

This year to accelerate the service, Nurses' kits, will include a HAIR CLIPPER, a very large saving can be realized with a little equipment.

H. Lariviere - Sept. Ind. Agency.

April 5th, 1948

To The Director, Indian Health Services, Ottawa, Ont.

Attention: Dr. O. Leroux, Reg. Supt., Quebec

Over orders for hair cutting equipment, I am referred to you for securing it, letter by Mr. P. Phelan, Chief, Training Division, his letter March 31, 1948 File No. 74-9-5 (E1).

The problem is this: The importance of CLEAN HEADS, to overcome poor school attendance and improve on elementary hygiene. I feel if the teachers at these schools had a little equipment, it would be easy matter to get the hair of the children cut, by some Indians or the parents.

I have ordered 4 HAIR CLIPPERS for nurses, to be part of their equipment to dispose of infected impetigo cases mainly.

It is not my intention to demand the TEACHERS OR THE NURSES to become "barbers", the whole thing is this, with a little equipment on the RESERVE, we can get these Indians to form the habit to do so by themselves.

Impetigo is costing about now $1,000.00 per year on MEDICAL ALONE, on WELFARE I cannot say. The equipment was ordered on "WELFARE AND TRAINING" for it was felt on this like many other details it was a matter of training, like on "knitting pins" and so on.

I would appreciate that my orders for HAIR EQUIPMENT be completed, to permit us, to push with our "training work" among these INDIGENOUS on what we can do for them and at the same time enjoy a reduced cost.

H. Lapiviere - Supt. Indian Agency.

October 28th, 1948.

Dear Mr. Edwardson,

We received your invoices covering time done by yourself, Angus and Melvin, on the new Obedjiwan School. It appears you ran short of logs suitable for the job, when I was at Obedjiwan Chief McQuish was to attend securing. I have not yet received the bills from the H.B.C. at Obedjiwan, in any event this will adjust during coming winter.

I note you used old Nemess' house to store the lumber and other material, if the roofing paper has not yet been delivered to Obedjiwan, I would appreciate that you see Mr. Kidgigs and ask to store until next spring, 40 rolls 15¢ green roofing.

As regard completing these buildings, we will endeavour to do so as early as possible in spring 1949, very likely we will do Manawan also immediately after, in any event during my next visit at Oskelanso, I will see you.

As regard payment of your salary also for Angus, for work done at Manawan - Nursing I presume, you have by now received payment in full, if not please advise. As regard payment for the Obedjiwan job, on account new regulations, effective October 4th, on Unemployment Insurance, it may cause a little delay, the invoices are going forward today and I am sure in Ottawa they'll do all they can to push settlement.

Yours very truly,

H. Lariviere, Supt. Indian Agency.

Mr. Magnus Edwardson,
Oskelanso River, Que.
October 28th, 1946.

To The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

Attention: Mr. B.F. Neary, Supt. of Education
Re: Obedjiwan New School

Mr. Magnus Edwardson, who went in to Obedjiwan, to do advance work on this job, reports as follows:

1.- Living quarters: Foundation and walls done.
2.- Wood shed: Walls done.
3.- Toilets: Teachers & school (2) walls done.
4.- School: Foundation done - cement piers.
5.- All Lumber shipped, stored in the old house of J.B. Nemess roof repaired to fully protect. In this house material for this job stored also, nails. He did not say definitely if the roofing paper Obedjiwan and was stored; in any event we know it reached Oskelaneo and it will be taken care of.

At Obedjiwan, taking ground into consideration, the buildings will be as follows:

1.- Storage - for wood - fuel - with partition for garden tools property of the school.
2.- Teachers residence same as for Nurses.
3.- Toilet for teachers.
4.- School - 20 x 40' (same size as at Waswanipi)
5.- School toilet.

All log job.

Location, near lake, beach, water supply easy to get at, school garden, around the buildings, on north side plenty of room for school yard, sidewalk logs in front all buildings and so.

..............
The new school will be on the west side of the Reserve and the Nursing Station on the east side, about \( \frac{1}{2} \) of a mile between, in direct line, in between with time, plenty of room for new buildings, with good drainage for a trail or road and houses, which should correct the old set up "rabbit trail street".

The present school, suitable for a class room, for the younger children, the old Mission House - now the Teachers residence, with some repairs easily done, the Mission would have no objections to allow its use for "Homemakers Club" weaving loom and other work along these lines. With this set up, when new school completed Obedjiwan should be able to improve and take care of the present needs for a number of years to come.

H. Lariviere - Supt. Indian Agency.

P.S. As regard material required to complete this job, you will be advise as soon as possible, latest in January 1948.

RE: Your letter Jan 6, 1949,
Your file #113-74 (El) - 322-5

In reply, the expenditure of $24.00 was incurred in connection with carload of lumber from LaSarre for Obedjiwan and Menawan Schools. Unfortunately the shipper did not follow our instructions on billing. Apparently through a refusal from the part of the station Agent, the question of interpreting tariff. As soon as we became aware of this we communicated with Mr. McLeod, manager of H.P.C., at Oskeleneo; considering, we felt it was fair to distribute the charges on a fifty-fifty basis for both schools.

Invoice amounting to $126.45 actually represents a charge for services rendered to us. Had Mr. McLeod declined to take care of our sick Indians and look after the unloading and rebilling of lumber, on the lumber alone it will have meant an extra expenditure of some $30.00 at least. He was asked to submit a separate Invoice, but unfortunately he overlooked and made a slight error when writing receipts, which we corrected on our original voucher, hoping it would be satisfactory to all.

In such cases it is my understanding we should not alter original invoices from suppliers, so it was presented as received. More, I am aware that the Company's Head Office object a great deal that their employees spend their time assisting us like in this case. However most of the Post employees are open to cooperation providing that if they make an error on billing or equal that if at all possible it be adjusted within our own services.

With Hudson's Bay Company it is understood any alterations, deductions, etc. they must be notified.

In this Agency, it is not altogether possible to operate without the good will and cooperation of our suppliers at various points. If for the least error they make, more so like in this case, we are not prepared to overlook certain
details we will lose their cooperation. At this office, owing to shortage of staff, long working hours, we are not altogether equipped to do extracts from Invoices from various sources. We are continuously asking to furnish us with separate bills for Welfare, Medical, Education, Nursing Stations, etc. As a whole I consider our suppliers are doing their best for they themselves often have not the staff to take care. And if we insist too much we will be the ones to suffer, and our cost will be much higher in many instances.

I can assure you we are doing the almost impossible to secure charges as desired by various divisions, but unfortunately we don't always get results, owing to communications most of the time it is felt better to clear as received. For example a minor error from Manowen say in fall, cannot be corrected before March or April.

(sgd) H. Lariviere

Att'n Mr. B.F. Neary, Supt. Education;

Further to our conversation when in Ottawa last, since I have prepared slowly to cover completion of Obedjiwan, Manawan and Mistassini schools.

Mr. Magnus Edwardson, who has been doing work for us on nursing stations and schools, is prepared to go in with others and do all this work this summer.

Considering, it is absolutely impossible to make arrangements for crews of men, their transportation, also supplies, at the last minute; and to do these three jobs this summer it means rushing in immediately after break up and if possible before, that is last trips. I would appreciate authority now to make arrangements to do this work on account season 1949-50.

As regard Waswanipi, it is only a matter of a man going in for about a month to complete details. Here, there is a plan underway to do some Indian houses, in any event some improvements. I estimate completion of the school will be possible probably through these other men, which means savings on transportation, etc.

Requisitions for supplies are being prepared now and I hope to be able to submit by early February for spring delivery if you have funds available on present fiscal year, or for early summer delivery as a charge to 1949-50 appropriations. Our summer program is developing to a new high, that is very heavy, and if we experience too many delays we won't be able to carry it out. Our medical service alone calls for 6 to 7 nurses in the field. Here as you know everything has to be worked out in full details to put it over. This with other things we have only 3 or 4 months to do it. Needless to say we must be prepared in advance and everything must be timed well ahead.

In reply, in this area, more so in remote areas, cost of travelling and food, is one that will vary a great deal, depending on men or men and if arrangements for travelling can be worked out ahead of time, combined with other transportation and so on and how much personal effects a person need to carry.

The following figures will give you a fair idea:

Basis: Oskelaneo River, Que.

One way to Mistassini:
Estimated Minimum $40.00 / $65.00
Maximum 100. / 325.00

One way to Waswanipi:
Estimated Minimum $25.00 / $65.00
Maximum 75.00 / 130.00

One way to Obedjiwan:
Minimum $30.00
Maximum 50.00

Here one or two, or three men, may cost same price.

Food, will vary also from place to place and depending on how much country food, one can get through the Indians, feeding a man above places with store and local fresh food, may cost $65.00 to $125.00 per month, it depends also on how many and so on.

At Manawan: It will work out about same as for Obedjiwan.

Hoping this information will assist you. Cost here is always at lowest when arrangements can be made well ahead of time, combined with Agency general affairs, on all matters.

Re: Your No. 322-5 (E2) April 25th, 1949

Attention: Mr. Doucet:

I wish to thank you for having sent the plan, together with official cover. I might say that about 2 years ago I discussed with Mr. B.F. Neary, Supt. of Education (in Booth Building) the question of log buildings and what he would care to have, your plan represent, his views at the time, but we had to make certain changes, owing to various conditions, Indian labor, size of logs, transportation (canoes and aircrafts).

The construction of log buildings for nursing stations, and schools, not only was originally intended to cover a building need, but to educate the Indians, to improve, on their own shelters.

On a log job, one point which is extremely weak, as a matter of fact not acceptable, is the two small windows, near front wall, at Waswanipi we placed in front, however I have noted that you took care, by allowing leeway if necessary.

For remote areas, the question of standard glasses is one very important, if we have variation on sizes, within a few years the damages are great and it usually end up with no widows, in any event, on requests for glasses, I never saw it fail, they ask "send me a glass for the side window or front door, you know the size."

The most important part, is that we have not yet received authority to go ahead, we are already late, I am scheduled to be at Manawan on the 19th. of May latest, at Mistassini on about June 6th, and we have many details to take care of, briefly after May 15th., we will swamp.

H. Lariviere - Supt. Indian Agency.

Your No. 322-5 (E) May 6th, 1949

Yours together with copy of Memorandum dated May 3/49, came to hand.

On school buildings, I took the same stand as I did on Nursing Stations, educating the Indians, create new ambitions, train them to work when possible and so on, through this type of buildings, make them realize that they can do something for themselves by themselves. Our Indians at Mistassini, Obegowan are very primitive, at Manawan improved.

Years ago when with a trading Company, to get business, furs and the usual, the firm decided to get houses made for the best trappers, some were made in Quebec City, pre-fabricated, others on the ground by number crews of carpenters from the cities, we furnished some of them, more for the top trappers, we allowed a house organ, portable, imported from France, the whole thing was more or less failure, the weak point, was it was too good, with that experience and better knowledge of the Indians, I feel "log jobs" where it applies, is the solution.

When the Nursing Stations buildings were first brought up, it was in Cochrane, Mr. Doucet was present, I hope this summer it will be possible to show Mr. Doucet the results obtained through it.

I always maintained primitive Indians, have to be trained for almost anything, over doing it on one point, might delay their progress for years, as you know they have plenty of time, more so when it is not within their ideas of things.

H. Lariviere - Supt. Indian agency.

July 14th, 1948

To Mr. Magnus Edvardson,
at Ibedjiwan, Que.,
via Oskelano River, Que.

Dear Mr. Edvardson,

Further to windows for this school, on my return at Amos, I re-checked specifications. I found that a certain which had been made in the first place, was to be cancelled with manufacturer, resulting now that they are shipping 6 windows BS lights 12 x 18", which means these windows will replace the windows provided for openings.

In order to take care, it will be necessary to adjust, by pulling down casings and likely logs, in between windows as you have it now.

These new large windows, are to go in, from center post, 3 on each side, between each window, considering the load, (roof etc.,) suggest a post between each. As regard window on side near front, at about false wall - partition, if preferred, this one may stay as it is, and will ship a window for it later.

As the new windows are considerably larger, I feel it should not be too much work, to put them in instead.

Yours very truly,

H. Lariviere — Supt. Indian Agency.

P.S. Your windows, doors, etc., should leave Amos, in a few days, on Oskelano. Henry St-Pierre can freight them in, by middle of next week. If short of paint, etc., let us know at once. There has been a mix-up and delay on shipments.
Ottawa, September 1, 1949.

Sir,

Referring again to your letter, No 152220, and dated 24th July, I beg to advise you that according to promise we investigated the case of the teacher of the Oka country school against whom your agent preferred charges of inattention and incompetency. The result has not been favorable to your Agent or his report. The Missionary who is acquainted with all the facts in the case denies that she lost eight days in June. He reports that she did not lose a day in that month except the two last days which were spent in examining the children and the distributing of prizes. The complaints seem to be purely personal. The Agent is said to have taken offence because the teacher refused to be coerced to do what was a part of the Agent's duty to do. Our Missionary declares the Agent himself is the incompetent one. He can neither read, write, nor understand the English tongue. More than once our Missionary has had to read and interpret his official letters, and frequently has made out his monthly report for him. Miss Wilson, the teacher in question, has left with no intention of returning. I thought it best to report the facts to you as they were reported to us so that you might know what value to attach in the future to any similar reports coming from the

Miss Carr comes to us highly recommended by Prof. Kneeland late of the McSill Normal, at present prof. of the McDonald College at Ste Anne de Beliveau. I visited the Country School at Oka several times during last autumn and found the order in the school fair, I was very much pleased with Miss Carr's methods of teaching and dealing with the children. have no knowledge, whatever, of Mr. Perillard having to go to the school to restore order. I shall make enquiry regarding that statement. Dear Sir:

Re Oka Country School.

It was my privilege, in company with Rev. J. D. Ellis, Chairman of the Montreal South District of our Church, to visit Oka Indian Mission a short time ago.

I would not advise the closing of the Country School and the attempt being made to bring the children from the Country to the Village School, for the following reasons:

1. The school building in the Village would not be large enough to accommodate all the children from the village and country who ought to attend.

2. The road leading from the country into the village has been recently opened through the woods and, we would judge, would be in a very bad condition for travel for a considerable length of time.

3. It is doubtful if satisfactory arrangements could be made for the carrying of the children from the country to the village school.

REPORT OF A.F. MacKENZIE ON THE OKA COUNTRY SCHOOL.

This school is a neat frame building on a stone foundation, the interior finished in wood and neatly painted both on the exterior and interior. The classroom is 20 feet by 15 feet and provides suitable accommodation for the number of children who attend. The furnishings are good and with some few exceptions sufficient for the needs of the school. An additional blackboard is needed, two chairs, a water tank, basins and towels, which I would recommend the agent be authorized to furnish. The closets are badly dilapidated and ought to be renewed at once, as they are beyond repair. I asked, Mr. Bertrand, the agent, to obtain an estimate of the cost of a suitable double closet, which he promised to do and submit to the Department for consideration.

SCHOOL SITE.

The site on which this school is situated erected was given the church authorities by two Indians, being the half of two lots and is only 40 feet by 75 feet. This is regrettable as there is no playground for the children. There is a driving shed at the rear of the school, but the entrance to it is only a few feet wide. Mr. Simons who owns the lot to the west of the school ground would be willing to grant a strip of land about 16 feet wide, which would give a little better playground and a better approach to the shed where the Indians tie their horses when they are attending church services, which are held in the school. As the purchase of this small strip of land from Mr. Simons would entail but a small expenditure (he is to submit an offer at a later date), I think it would be well for the Department to make the purchase and add this piece of ground to the lot.

MEMORANDUM.

Rev. Mr. Whitebeans of Oka called on me today and brought up several matters in connection with the schools there. One is in regard to the driving of pupils to school. He says that there are only two children living in the village who should attend the Country school and he recommends that these two children be placed in the French Methodist Institution at Montreal. We can get them in there for $60.00 a year each. If these children are so placed it would reduce the cost of driving the other pupils to school by $10.00 a month. Of course the children will not have to be driven until the bad weather sets in in the fall and only until the fine weather in the spring.

Mr. Whitebeans then brought up the question of getting a little more ground around the Country Schoolhouse. He says that the owner has put up a prohibitive price, but he thinks that he could be induced to take a fair amount for the sixteen feet that we would require. If he will take $25.00 I would recommend that we pay it.
When we secure this land for the Country School we want either a new shed or the present one extended.

There is a claim for rent for the school premises in the village. I believe this has been recognized, but there are five or six heirs entitled to share in it and one of them is away in the States and his signature cannot be obtained. The others have all signed and I think that it would be only fair to pay the money to the people that have signed and hold the balance for the man that is entitled to it, unless a release is obtained in the meantime.

Mr. Whitebeans is sending in some applications for the admission of Oka children to the Shingwauk Home.

Mr. Whitebeans stated that he understood that some of the Indians were willing to enlist, but were turned back because they had not the consent of the Department.

The names of the two children that Mr. Whitebeans recommends should be placed in the French Methodist Institution at Montreal are Florence and Arthur Touissant.

Dear Sir,

When organising the work for the Oka Country School, I took it upon myself to make some slight alteration. The children are in seven different stages of progress, so I have organised them into as many standards. For seven weeks I have done my best to follow in the old way to which they had become accustomed, of keeping these seven classes working at one the same time, but in different sets of work. Under these circumstances I could only get in about ten minutes—sometimes more, sometimes less—of a lesson with each class, but no time have I been able to give a thorough lesson to any one section. Oral lessons even could not be given collectively, because it is impossible to successfully adapt Junior & Senior methods to one another. I have tried several schemes of work & organisation but they will not work with success while Juniors & Seniors continue to be mixed the whole time.

After thinking it well over, I decided to keep the Juniors for 3 hrs only in the morning (from 9 am to 12 pm), giving my whole time to them; while the Seniors were set to private study or written work. The Juniors I dismissed at 12 o'clock for the remainder of the day; from one o'clock to quarter to four I gave my full time to the Senior portion of the School. I find it works much better as by so doing I am able to get in some thorough work with each section; but some of the parents are objecting, whose objections seem to be based simply on the ground of my method being an innovation. I have had fifteen years experience as a teacher, having interested in my work, I assure you that I have only the interest of the children at heart. I would therefore like to ask you to give
me your written permission to try this method, at any rate for one month, to see how it works. If it is not successful, then we can easily go back to the old method.

Waiting your favorable reply,

I am,
Yours faithfully,
Laura B. Dickinson.

Sir,

May I ask if it would be possible to enforce the act for the compulsory attendance of the children at above school? At present the majority of them attend very irregularly. Not only does slackness in this respect prove to be bad for the children both intellectually and morally, but it makes the work very disheartening. Myself as teacher; as all the work put in appears to be only so much waste energy.

Sirs,

Replying to your letters of the 5th and also 26th.

Ultimo No 152220/1 in reference to the complaints from here to the Department about the teacher's methods in her school, I beg to say, that after looking into the matter carefully I find that the complaints have hardly any resemblance of truth in them. To any competent and unprejudiced observer it is clearly seen that the Teacher has the welfare and the interest of the children at heart. She has a natural love for children and knows how to manage them, and I gather from what I have learned about her, she has had great success in her fifteen years teaching experience. In spite of the absence of corporal punishment of any kind in her school, she has in the short time she has had this school secured a first class discipline. Only once has she sent a boy home from school for repeatedly day after day failing to do what she wants him to do, and as a result, was cured, I'm told, of his neglectful habit.

With regard to the objection by some of the parents to the experiment, by the Department's permission, of teaching the younger children in the forenoon only, I cannot see any way out of the difficulty. There are so many different grades it is impossible for one person to handle them all at the same time for whole days, so she is trying this plan of giving all her time to the juniors in the forenoon. The seniors during the forenoon are given desk work, which does not take very much of the teacher's time, and they do not lose any time as work is given them the whole time. In the afternoon the teacher has just seniors. By this plan the juniors get more work done in the half a days than if they were kept in all day and the teacher giving only occasional attention to them. I am fully convinced that these juniors will learn more in one year by this plan than in any other year before. Parents are remarking already of how much their children have learned since the teacher came. The plan is not altogether new, by any means, as it is followed in hundreds of schools throughout the country.

These objectors are not competent to judge about these matters, and further they are very unreasonable and will never consider from any other viewpoint but theirs. Facts can be given to prove, that we have not had as good a teacher in the last ten years than the present one. The objectors should never be encouraged but should be told to co-operate with the teacher in her endeavors to elevate their children. The teacher tells me that she notices in the children's behaviour the influence of these complainers on them and makes it harder work for her.

Received today your letter dated Feb. 13th re. starting a sewing class here to make garments for the children. Way I say that conditions here are such that the idea is hardly practicable. The severe weather & bad condition of the roads at present, besides the home claims of the women & girls, also the distance of the homes from one another, make it difficult to gather them together at a central place of meeting. This course too, would cause a delay in the churn having the clothes. As the sewing class could not be for more than an hour or two at the most & that in the evening (we have very poor lights to work by & the sewing would have to be done by hand) - it would be at least a week or two before the garments were ready; the churn are in need of them now. It certainly is best that material should be given them to make up instead of ready-made clothes; but may I suggest that they be allowed to do it in their own homes where some of them have sewing machines. In this way, the garments would be ready more quickly, there would be no need for the women & girls to neglect their home duties to come to the class. As the roads are at present, the journey to & from a place of meeting would take at least an hour extra for most of them. I am willing to superintend this work if you wish it, & to give all the help I can to those making the clothes.

My objections are not raised through any unwillingness to start the sewing class. I have twice tried it before, but the women found it claimed too much of their time, when they could do it at home in half the time, & superintend home duties as well.

May I also suggest that perhaps it would be a good thing to start a sewing class in the summer months. After the planting is over before the harvesting begins. The garments when finished could be left in charge of some responsible person, to be ready for use when the winter comes.

Faithfully yours,

Laura E. Dickinson

Sir,

In pursuance with the instructions contained in your letter of February 13th, I proceeded to Oka and met the Indians in Council, as well as making personal calls at some of the homes of the children. From observations I was able to make I do not think it advisable, in the meantime, to provide clothing for any of the children in order to enable them to attend school. The fathers of the three families mentioned by Chief Peter Angus are earning livelihood as well as other Indians and are in position to clothe their children. The school is quite near their homes, not farther than half a mile. To begin to clothe school children here would be an unwise departure, these Indians are now the greatest parasites of the Department and should be made to realize that the Department does not exist for the sole object, as they think, of feeding and clothing the Oka Indians.

With regard to those parents who do not send their children to school and defying the threats of the truant officer, I did not call upon them for the following reason:

The roads owing to the severity of the winter have been practically in an impassable condition, and living as they do over two miles from the school, and the children would have to travel across an open country it is no wonder that they were unable to attend school regularly.
The teacher, Miss Dickenson, had evidently lost control of her school and interest in her work, particularly during the last few weeks, and the Indians had serious complaints against her, therefore, lost confidence of the children and with it had outlived her usefulness. The fault, to my mind, was not altogether with the Indians. The school was closed and had been closed for two days the day I called. The teacher informed me that she had tendered her resignation to the Mission authorities and that she expected to leave at the end of February. In conversation, with Rev. A. A. Radley of St. Lambert, who has charge of the Oka Indian Mission on behalf of the Methodist Missionary Society, he informed me that Miss Dickenson's resignation as teacher of the Oka Country School had been accepted.

With the incoming of a new teacher, I am inclined to think, the attendance at school will prove satisfactorily. I would, therefore, leave the matters complained of, by Chief Peter Angus, as they are until after the new teacher is well started in the work. In the case of Etienne, who defies the Department to punish him for not sending his children to school, I would give him another chance and see how he acts after the change of teachers, and if he still continues to be defiant I would recommend legal action being taken against him and the result will no doubt be a salutary as an example to all other recalcitrants.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Oka, March 16th, 1917.

Dear Sir,

I wish to inform you that I have been given a list of children who have not attended school since its re-opening the 13th March. I called on all the parents and some have responded while others have not, because they lack clothing and boots. I think it would be wise for the Department to furnish these people with the articles I asked for and promised me when I was in Ottawa.

With regard to the children of Leon Etienne, I would not ask anything on their behalf as their father is too unwilling to send them to school. He says "such laws do not belong to him;" he is following the Indian idea of freedom. I am surprised at your way of treating people like him. His mother is getting regularly relief from the Agent notwithstanding her children are engaged to support her as she has given them all her property. They are all followers of Thunderwater. If the Department intends to enforce the compulsory school act then Leon Etienne should be the first man to make an example of.

The Indians are very bitter against me for being a truant officer and have asked me to resign or they will do me injury. I will not resign, I would rather fall at their hands than do what they wish. I should like the Department to supply me with something with which to protect myself in my travels among them in the event of my being assaulted by them.

(Signed) Chief Peter August

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter No. 152220, dated Dec. 26th, 1918, in which you said my explanation re. report of lack of discipline in school were satisfactory, and "it is hoped that in future there will be no further cause of complaint."

I beg to say I don't believe there was any cause for complaint. On Friday last...
Chief Peter Angas called with the complaint that he heard that the children were playing with dolls in school. I replied that last December two girls brought dolls a time or two to play with at noon, but the moment I observed them in school hours I forbade it. He also inquired as to time of closing school. I have been giving no recess in the afternoon, and letting school out at half-past three, the primary class at half-past two, also on Friday once a month at half-past two to attend the ladies' aid which we organized for the uplift of the women. I understand that similar complaints have been made.
To Mrs. Bertrand, the Indian agent, and to Mrs. Primeau, the School Inspector at St. Jerome.

Now permit me to say, I did not seek this position. The Rev. A.A. Radley urgently requested me to take the school. He assured me I was well recommended as to ability and character by Inspector McQuatt and Mr. Beiler, with whom I have been acquainted for some years. I hold a B.A. degree from McGill University, and a certificate of a successful summer course at Macdonald College. I have several years experience in teaching—four years and a half at this Oka Country School.
When I came here twenty-seven years ago the pupils—even the most advanced—were hardly able to utter a sentence in English. After three years teaching I left them speaking, reading, and singing fairly well. I placed eighteen bibles in their hands, and as many hymnbooks, at my own expense. I interested my friends in getting places for them and four chief lingers among the number-found situations among my people.

I don't think I should have to spend my time carrying on a correspondence to maintain my position here. I am doing my utmost for their betterment.

Reverend Sir,

The Department has received a petition signed by a number of the Indians on the Oka Reserve, in which they request that the services of Miss Frances E. Saunders, teacher of the Oka Country School, be dispensed with and that another teacher be engaged. These Indians have been making complaints during the past two years regarding the work Miss Saunders is performing in the classroom. They state that she has no control over the children and consequently the discipline is very poor, also that their children are making no progress in their studies. They request that a younger teacher be engaged.

We have in the past taken this matter up with our Agent and the Rev. J. J. Oke, Missionary on the Reserve, and they have stated that these charges are without foundation. The fact, however, remains that the Indians refuse to send their children to school and the majority of them, at least, are very much prejudiced against Miss Saunders. In view of these facts, it would appear to be desirable to make a change in the teacher at this school. We find that when the Indians are against a teacher, with or without good reason, although the teacher may be competent, it is better to make a change. These complaints have now been coming in to the Department for the past two years, and I submit for your consideration the advisability of the Methodist Church authorities making a change in the teacher at the Oka Country School. It might be that the services of Miss Saunders could be utilized elsewhere.

It will also be necessary to obtain a teacher for the Oka Village School, as Miss Helen Earl, the former teacher, has resigned.

Both Miss Saunders and Miss Earl were appointed through the Chairman of the Montreal South District of the Montreal Conference, and I shall be pleased if you will take the matters referred to in this letter up with your Church authorities in that district.

Your early attention to this matter will oblige,

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

By dear Sir;

I have your letter of July 15th, signed by A. F. McKenzie, Action Assistant Deputy and Secretary, admitting a mistake in a previous letter in not noting that Miss Vera Simons had been appointed to succeed Miss Earl at the Oka Village School.

Now, about Miss Saunders not being satisfactory at the Oka Country School. Rev. Robert Smith, Chairman of the Montreal District, wrote me on April 12th, enclosing Miss Saunders' application to be employed as teacher for this school next year. I replied to his letter, telling him that I knew of no reason why her services should not be retained, but told him that I had written to the Rev. Arthur Barner about this, as he superintends our Indian Missions. Mr. Barner did not know any reason why she should not be re-engaged and I consequently told Mr. Smith that so far as I knew it would be satisfactory to re-engage her - which he did.

I presume that I should have written to the Department, rather than to Mr. Barner, but as the Indian Work has recently come under my supervision I have not been as familiar with the method of procedure as I trust I shall be from this time forward.

Sir:-

Sir:

MEMORANDUM FOR FILE.

Mr. Boutcher, teacher of the Oka Country Indian Day School, called to see me today and explained some of the difficulty he is encountering at his work. There is a clique of Indians, headed by Mrs. Ernest Simon, who are pagan and disloyal, and are doing their best to hurt the teacher's reputation as well as destroy his influence. This is rather an expensive arrangement for him, as he will have to ride a horse in the winter time to and from his work. Rev. Sir:

The continued poor attendance at the Country School on the Oka Indian Reserve and the inability of the truant officer to induce the parents to send their children has led the Department to seriously contemplate closing the school for an indefinite period. The attitude of the parents in this section of the Reserve makes it very difficult for the Department to either enforce the law or conduct a school successfully. It is, therefore, thought that the closing of the school may have a salutary effect, and the local Indian Agent has been informed that such action will be taken if conditions do not improve.

A complaint was made a short time ago by certain of the Indians regarding the conduct of the teacher, Mr. Selby Boutcher, and also objections were raised to the recent change in the truant officer. The Department after carefully considering these complaints is not prepared to make a change in either the teacher or truant officer.

Reverend Sir:

Since my No. 20-1-1 of the 18th instant, an Oka delegation has visited Ottawa with reference to the Country Day School. There is a very strong clique of Indian parents who are opposed to continuing the services of Mr. Selby Boucher, the teacher. The delegation was informed that the Department intended to close the school unless the attendance materially increased. Promise was given that, if a good average attendance was secured for the months March to June, inclusive, the Department would not only keep the school open but would make arrangements for a new and better qualified teacher. I regret, therefore, to inform you that in any case the services of Mr. Boucher will not be required after June 30th.

The Department does not consider that Mr. Boucher is largely to blame for the present difficulties and the poor attendance. However, I am convinced that the Country Day School would never function satisfactorily as long as he is the incumbent. The clique opposed to him are very strong in the locality and it is not considered advisable to again enlist the services of the R.C.M.P. at the present time in an effort to bring about satisfactory attendance. As soon as you have conferred with your representatives, I shall be pleased to hear from you.

Dear Mr. Ferrier,

It has taken me a long time to avail myself of your invitation to write you personally about the work here, but I was waiting to see how things were going. I am not sure yet, but I really am hoping that the "little more than an opportunity," of which you told me in your office, is going to be realized.

The average attendance at the country school so far are as follows:

- September: 11.42
- October: 14.50
- November: 16.42
- To date in December: 20.80

I have now 37 children on the roll, and I know of only three more children of school age in my district.

The children are doing good work, and the school is properly graded up to grade five. I decided to get the children down to good hard slogzing work at reading, writing, arithmetic and English, and although the going was up-hill, it proved a successful policy.

Now as to methods.

I soon realized that the real problem was not with the children, but with the parents, and I decided to tackle the job.

I began by writing a letter to the agent to be read at the council of chiefs, quite recently elected. I pointed out in my letter that the chiefs had a great opportunity to co-operate with the schools, and asked two...
things:

1. that they would urge upon the people the importance of sending the children to school every day.
2. that they - with the parents - would back up the teacher in every way possible.

The chiefs responded unanimously and enthusiastically. They asked the agent to write me a letter of appreciation (which he didn't do) and promised me, separately and collectively, their full support. And they have given it, and are honestly using their influence for the school in every way.

The next move was to establish direct contact with the people. So we arranged an exhibition of school work. I sent out by post invitations (as per the enclosed) to all the parents to come to the school one Friday afternoon, an invitation to which only the parents of one child did not respond. We had about forty of them at the school, in addition to the mayor and council who were also invited.

The programme is enclosed. The children did all their work in the presence of their parents and did it well. They added a dignified little programme - it really was a gem - after the exhibition of work, and after that the senior girls served refreshments.

The parents were swept off their feet, and were loud in their praises. They used more complimentary adjectives than I thought they knew, and quite eloquent speeches were made by the chiefs. The feeling abroad is fine, and I really believe that I have the full confidence of the people. In some cases older pupils who had given up school are coming back.

Of course, on an Indian reserve all things are possible. I would not like to prophesy how long I shall be able to hold this. But I am working hard. The parents really realize that the children are making progress, and are quite delighted.

As regards the future,

Mr. Oke and I are contemplating a house to house visitation soon, and at Christmas I shall send out properly made out reports on each child's work. In the
New Year I am contemplating another gathering of parents which shall be of a more social character. In the early summer I am planning for an exhibition of games, etc.

Here is one phase of all this which suggests itself to me. I wonder whether if I wrote an official letter I could get a grant—a small one—towards these efforts to put the community behind the school. Surely it is worth while & is having excellent results. My school has asked for nothing else, so far not even for school supplies. What do you think? Would a request for a grant of $20 or so, be considered? I am about that much out of pocket, anyway. Furthermore, we shall not be asking for large grants or things of that kind.

Please excuse so long a letter, but I was anxious to let you see what we are really doing. I am feeling fairly confident, and I hope you will be fairly satisfied.

With kindest regards to yourself and Mrs. Irvine,

Yours sincerely,

H. E. Elburne.
Ottawa, December 17, 1925.

Dear Mr. [Name],

I enclose a copy of your School Report for the term ending March 31st. I hope you will find it satisfactory.

I would like to thank the parents for the help and support they have given the teacher during the past six months. It is because of this help that the children have made progress.

Because I know that you are interested, I venture to suggest the following ways in which the parents can help the children at school:

**ATTENDANCE:**

The attendance has dropped a little during the past few weeks, and I am anxious that it shall increase again.

Almost the best way to help the teacher is to send the children to school EVERY DAY. The greatest trouble we have is with children who come for a day or two, and then stay away for a day or half day. The children can only do well in school if they attend regularly every day. When one child in a grade is away, it interferes with the work of every child in the grade. It is hoped that the parents will continue to help by seeing that the children come EVERY DAY.

**ENGLISH:**

Another way in which the parents can help is by encouraging the children to speak English. English is the language in which the children are taught, and the language in which they do their lessons. The better they understand English the quicker they will learn other subjects. You can help in this matter in the following three ways:

1. By encouraging the children to speak in English to the teacher, and to each other, when they are in school.
2. By allowing them sometimes to speak in English when they are at home.
3. By letting them try to read books and papers at home.

**HOMEWORK:**

Some of the children are given a little work to do at home at night. This is never very much, but it helps the children to study when they are away from the teacher. The parents can help much by allowing the children to do this work, and by encouraging them to do it well.

In addition to the above, I shall be glad if the parents will ask the children sometimes to show them their school work books, so that the children may know that their parents are interested in their work. The children are always allowed to take home any book they like.

If there is any way in which I can be of use, I shall be glad if you will let me know. I am generally in the school from four o'clock in the afternoon to half past four, and from seven o'clock to nine o'clock at night. At these times I am always glad to meet any of the parents.

I hope that we shall continue to work in the future as well as we have in the past.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Dear Sir:

After working for a year at the above school, I venture to suggest that the Department take under consideration making provision for the following things: In making these suggestions I have in view the fact that the people of the community are genuinely interested in all educational matters and it looks to me as if there will be considerable advance in the near future, and I am desirous that this advance shall be made along the broadest possible lines.

MEDICAL INSPECTION: Can the Department arrange to have the children examined by a doctor or qualified nurse? An examination of this kind was recently made in a nearby school, by Dr. A. Prevost. It would be very satisfactory if the same doctor be employed for this school. I would suggest, however, that the examination be a thorough one, including examination of eyes, ears, nose, throat, lungs. Unless the examination is thorough it would defeat its own purpose. Speaking roughly, it would seem to me that an examination along the lines generally given to applicants for admission to a residential school would be what is needed. I shall be very glad if the Department will consider this matter.

INSTRUCTION IN SEWING: For some time I have been considering ways and means to give to the girl pupils instruction in sewing. Would it be possible for the Department to employ the services of Miss Myrtle Oke for this purpose? I would suggest that Miss Oke be asked to give one hour a week for this purpose, with a fair remuneration and provision for travelling from Oka Village to the country school. I have reason to believe that such provision would be very welcome to the parents and children. Miss Oke has had previous experience of this kind of work in one of the Indian residential schools in British Columbia.
SEATING ACCOMMODATION: It would seem to be a wise course to supply to the school a different kind of desk for the scholars. At present they are supplied with double desks of an antiquated design, and in many cases not at all fitted to the size of the child. Most of these desks are throw-outs from another school which is now adequately equipped. At the country school there are all kinds of desks, all of an obsolete pattern, many of them broken, none of them fastened to the floor, and practically all the same size. It would be a very wise proceeding to install about two dozen single desks such as have been installed in the Oka Village school and in many other Indian schools of which I have knowledge. I would ask the Department to take this matter very seriously under consideration.

I desire to emphasize that in making these requests I am not doing so without sufficient reason, and more particularly because I am sure that the people of the community are seized with the need for an advance, educationally, and that if properly guided and adequately equipped, the school will exercise a very great influence in the next few years.

Yours respectfully,

H. E. Eburne,
Teacher
