Dear Sir,

During the last twelve months I have, with the assistance of the Rev. J. J. Oke, gone very carefully into the situation in this settlement as far as the schools are concerned.

I beg to submit the following statement:

Number of children of school age in the settlement: 86
Number of children attending school: (This is the total average attendance at both village school and country school combined) 35

Percentage of children who should attend the Village School: ------------------------ 60%
Percentage of children who should attend the Country School: ------------------------ 40%

Average attendance at the Village School in relation to the number of children of school age in its constituency,------------------------ 30%

Average attendance at the Country School, in relation to the number of children of school age in its constituency,------------------------ 60%

The above figures are based upon the position at the end of the June quarter. I have reason to believe that the number of children attending the schools will improve a little during the coming term.

It should be pointed out that there are a number of children who live in a part of the settlement from which it is at times exceedingly difficult to reach either of the schools without some method of transportation. There is, indeed, a
My good case for an additional school in this particular part of the settlement.

Another fact that enters into the situation is that there is coming into being a very decided "school consciousness" among the people. They are extremely interested in all school matters, and one is frequently met with the request that the children be sent away to school. As an indication of this decided interest it can be mentioned that at the Country School there has been since the opening of school on the Ist. inst. what is practically a hundred per cent attendance from its own constituency. The Village school will open to-morrow, and, I expect, will also see a decided increase in attendance.

The foregoing facts, together with other considerations which can be brought forward at a later time if required, seem to me to point very definitely in the direction of a consolidation at one point of all school work, with adequate provision for the transportation of pupils to and from school.

This appears to be the more desirable now that there is in the village a building which with certain alterations could be made into a very satisfactory consolidated school.

Two points seem to me to emphasise this need. One is that the growth in attendance at the schools is parallel with the necessity of taking up the work of the higher grades of the Public School course. When a school goes much beyond sixteen or seventeen pupils, it is a very difficult thing to do the work of the higher grades, and at the same time do efficient work in English in the lower grades. Of course I would not make this statement apply to all schools, but I think it does very definitely apply to schools like ours where the language difficulty has to be met.

The other point is this: it appears to have been the custom in the past to send away to school all children who reached Grade 5 standing. This has entailed a series of grants from the Department which will not be necessary if the work is done here. In this connection I should point out that there are quite a number of scholars now about to enter these higher grades. By teaching them here we are saving the Department the necessity of a grant, but I feel that the teaching here would be of far better a quality under a consolidated system. It can also be stated that the custom of sending children away is not only expensive to the Department but also to the parents.

You will, of course, understand that I am not looking forward to any immediate change, but I am asking whether the Department will give us the assurance that we may work towards this end. The advantage of at least a two roomed school with separate teachers for the Junior and Senior work, and with provision for teaching domestic and handicraft subjects seems very obvious.
I do not think that the people of the settlement are ready for the change. It will be a matter both of education and demonstration before they really see its value. It is along these lines, though, that, if the Department gives us any encouragement, we can do a good deal of quiet preparatory work.

The extremely tentative nature of this letter has prevented me from putting the case at all fully, but I shall be quite glad to give any further information or to render any assistance in my power.

I should add that I have not discussed this matter with anyone except the Rev. J. J. Oke, and Mr. Agent Harbour.

I hope that the Department will not consider this letter at all presumptuous. It has been written solely because of the obvious need and the more obvious possibilities.

Yours respectfully,

H. E. Elburne

Dear Sir,

I desire to inform you that matters in connection with the above school are not as satisfactory as they have been.

As an indication, I may say that the average attendance at school is now only seventeen as compared with 27 two weeks ago, and it will probably drop a little lower yet.

There seems to be dissatisfaction with me partly because I am a servant of the Department, and partly because I desire to act impartially in my dealings with the children and the parents. The people seem quite unable to understand the latter attitude, while, as regards the former, I believe that you are fully cognisant of the difficulty of the situation.

It may illustrate the position to say that at a recent meeting of the parents objection was taken to my obtaining supplies and equipment for the school without previously consulting the band. (It should be understood that this has no reference to the properly elected council.) In reply to this objection, I suggested the appointment of a small advisory committee of parents to act with me. I was then asked if this committee could run the school entirely independently of the Department, and when I replied very definitely in the negative, the suggestion was refused. However, my apparent advocacy of the policy of the Department has brought about an atmosphere of suspicion and distrust.

Another difficulty has been that in a recent distribution of clothing grants from the Department, I acted with impartiality, and prepared a list of those who were actually in need. This has brought about obvious results, and I have had to put up with a good deal of nastiness.
I am the more apprehensive because this kind of atmosphere often breeds minor grievances and complaints—real and imaginary—which can undo very much really hard work. This has already proved to be the case to some degree.

I do not think there is anything in the situation that cannot be overcome with patience and a kindly and consistent firmness, but I feel it incumbent upon me to advise you of the existing tendency.

I am also anxious, of course, to safeguard my work in the event of any complaints that may reach the Department, and at the same time hopeful that you will send me any instructions or advice that you would desire me to follow.

I regret that I have had to trouble you in the matter.

Yours respectfully,

H.E. Burne
Teacher.

Dear Sir,

On the back of the school register there is an instruction to teachers to inculcate independence, industry, self-maintenance and to discard charity and pauperism.

In pursuance of these instructions I yesterday taught a lesson, the chief points of which I summed up as follows:

1. Laziness and idleness are to be condemned.
2. Every man should work for everything he gets.
3. To receive things without working for them is objectionable.
4. It is wrong for any person to expect others to support them.

I have taught these identical lesson once each year I have been here, and it has passed without notice. But this year I have been subjected to a veritable furnace of criticism, complaints and threats. For the threats and criticism I care nothing, but I am a little apprehensive of complaints that may be made, and I think it quite advisable to notify you.

The lesson in question was couched in extremely mild terms, but in order to hold the children's attention I made it fairly emphatic.

If I am at fault in giving this lesson I desire to be so advised, although I think the response is due to the fact that my children are beginning to do a little thinking for themselves, to which the parents object.
In any case I would ask the Department to safeguard me against complaints that may be made in so far that I was endeavouring to follow out faithfully my instructions and teaching that which I believe is the Department's own attitude.

Dear Sir,

I have just received a letter from Dr. Colin Young, acting secretary of the Board of Home Missions of the United Church of Canada, informing me that my services will not be required after the end of the present school year.

I have to inform the Department that I have been making arrangements to take over a position in connection with residential schools in England, after June, 1930, and that this post will not be available until then, although nominations are made this year. If I have to leave here this June I shall be at a loss to know how to arrange things for a whole year.

I have worked in connection with residential schools for fourteen years, and I have given to the Department every ability and every scrap of energy I possess. In this particular post I have laboured desperately—often against most disagreeable opposition—to make this work a success. I have given to the Department all I have in time and ability. I have never shirked and have given my all.

I beg to make a request. In view of my length of service, and in view of the fact that I have been a loyal servant of the Department and that I have received anything but approbation from those who knew my work, will the Department grant me one year's grace before I resign, and allow me to continue until June 1930.

Sir,

With reference to your letter of the 30th ultimo I beg to say that I was not surprised to receive said communication, for the same question had come before the council some time ago, when I thought it was not necessary to report, because I was of the opinion that the complaints were not serious.

Dear Mr. Ferrier,

As stated in any other letter of the same date, I appreciate an investigation being made here.

There are some things I have wanted to talk with you about, but hope that things would smooth out without troubling you.

The present difficulty originated I believe with Eva Simms, daughter of the former janitor. They continued during the weeks in September. I clean the building after four o'clock and they came in the morning.

One the morning of Friday Sept 6th I remarked that there seemed to be some misunderstanding and suggested that we see Mr. Harboer. She went out but came back bringing her aunt Simms who was apparently bent on quarreling. I refused to stand.

Eva accused me of turning children out of school and ordered...
Genesis Nelson. I replied "I will not quarrel." Genesis is the only one of the twins whose names were mentioned when I visited your office last spring, who has wanted to come back to school this year. His people took it well and kept his sister in school.

Genesis is this fall; has been in school regularly over five years and is still in Part IV. His habits are not good and I consider him an evil influence in the school.

When Eva and Mrs. Earnest Simon said they would not quarrel, they left here and got busy among the people. Then Drang the fell at 9 o'clock there were no children here. I stayed at the desk. About 9.20 Mrs. Gabriel and Mrs. Nicholas came with their children to find out if it were true that there was no school, as they had been told so by Eva and Louis Simon. While they were there Martha (Genesis sister) came. She had heard the fall. Paul Simon's little girl came at noon.

Last June I talked with the girls about not coming to school this year, and insisted taking up the sewing, cooking and other work I want to teach the school and C.H.I.T., together.
They seemed to be pleased. One mother also regarded it as a good thing.

I am quite sure that the matter of their not attending daily would have caused no trouble but for Eva Simon, who wished to make trouble and choose that as a talking point. I believe they hold that if the children are kept from coming to school they can then be rid of the teacher.

I am sorry to be a disturbing element, let I hope, and am giving my best them any best.

Yours respectfully,

Eva Simon.

P.S. I have just learned that Eva Simon has hopes of securing the position as teacher of the country school.

V.E.S.

Dear Mr. Ferrier:

After close study and observation of the situation in the Country School I discovered that the complaint had no reference to Miss Simmons' character or her ability as teacher.

The trouble is a keen sense of frustration.

It was thought Miss Simmons' health would never stand the strain of the work and would eventually resign as a result. It was hoped then that one of her own would be appointed but events proved otherwise. Added to the disappointment the Caretaker's services were dispensed with and all this affecting the same family. Then came the decision of the Dept. that pupils at the age of fifteen or over and backward in their studies should be graduated from school. Thus the sense of frustration spread almost over the entire community.

The pupils and parents had hoped that by returning to school for a short while in the fall they would be granted clothing boots and so forth. The majority of whom as a rule never returned to school after receiving them.
under these circumstances it was quite natural to blame somebody. They might have blamed the Agent, Mr. Harbour or myself with so much truth behind the complaint as against Miss Simcoe. She became the victim though no fault of hers.

Once a few of them suffered a sense of frustration it was quite easy for the feeling to spread by contagion and suggestion and sympathy.

I have had a talk with some of the most interested I saw the futility of argument when the emotions were so aroused. The feelings can only be overcome by letting them see the facts of the case. Only then can we hope the people to react normally again.

I am giving you my observations for what they are worth.

Dear Dr. Cochrane:

As I informed you in my telegram of the 19th instant, Mr. Ferrier visited Oka yesterday, to enquire into conditions at the Country Indian Day School. Dear Sir,

Your letter addressed to the Principal, Macdonald College has been handed to me. In reply, I regret to state that there are no male teachers available at this time of the year. All Protestant teachers make engagements in the spring for the following year.

In the Province of Quebec, school contracts are yearly contracts, terminating on the 1st June. Therefore, all school boards and all teachers making changes make up their minds, and enter into new contracts long before that date. For this reason, it is impossible to get teachers after the 1st June. I would, therefore, advise your Department to follow at Oka the procedure of the rest of the Province, and engage teachers in the spring, when they are available.

You state that you desire a male teacher of experience and tact at a salary of $600 to $1000 per annum, together with a heated apartment.

In reply, I may say you are very unlikely to get any male teacher, with a Protestant diploma at any rate, to accept this position at this small salary. I do not think in fact that you are likely to get any applications from any Protestants, as better positions and higher salaries are available in our regular schools.

Yours faithfully,

Sir:-

Last fall when the agent, Mr. F. Brisbois, gave news of there being no distribution of clothing, a few families provided their children with clothing. These children came regularly last fall and are still doing so, weather permitting. Since Christmas Mrs. S. Nicholas wrote to the Dept. and got clothing for their children. These children did not come regularly last fall and they have never come this year. I am of the opinion that since these children have been provided for, the ones who are coming regularly should be treated likewise. Their clothing and footwear is not so good for this cold weather. I want you to understand that I am not in favour of giving clothing to the children. Those who really want their children to have an education will provide for them, and anyway 80% of those who get the clothing do not attend school, as in the case of the Nicholas family. Your Dept. does exceptionally well when it provides books, etc., but since the one family has been helped, the others should be also. I believe in either no distribution or a distribution to all, as the one family is as well off as the other here.

It has been brought to my attention that your council here, the chief of which is Harry Oke, has been purposely withholding the distribution of clothing of those children who are regular in attendance. It has also been the cause of the discontinuance of the mid-day bowl of soup which all the children need as they come from a distance of from one half to three miles to school. In this connection I would like to inform you that it has been done with an end in view. Harry Oke has a sister who he wishes to have appointed teacher here. Last spring this council reported me to the Department as closing school early in the afternoon. This was a falsehood as can be proved by my wife and myself. It was done with the same purpose in view, and several people were asked to report me for imagined misdemeanours so that I should be asked to resign.
By this means he also stands a chance of being appointed Truant Officer. I may say that a local truant officer would be of no use here. That has been tried before and it did not work. I would like to suggest that the Dept. write to the defaulting parents and warn them. Then if that did no good, a Provincial could be sent once a month, get my report and visit the parents concerned. These parents say that they have nothing against me and they always promise to send their children to school any time that I ask them. But the children never arrive. As the attendance is the lowest it has ever been I advise some steps be taken by the Department.

Further, I have pretty good proof that Mr. Whitebean, the minister, has said that this is my last year here because I do not have a Sunday School. When I came here I looked over previous Sunday School records and found them far from favourable, and as there was a Sunday School in the village, I saw no reason for it here. Last winter I consulted with Dr. Barner on this topic and he agreed with me. Mr. Whitebeans tried it last fall and it fell flat. Of course the minister wants his daughter to have the position here. Mine seems to be a heavenly task when so many covet it.

I should like to know if it is really necessary for the people to have prayer meetings in the school here twice a week. On Thursday afternoon we lose 10 or 15 minutes gathering up the books, pencils, erasers etc., getting ready for services in the evening. Friday we lose the same amount of time distributing them in the morning. Then we collect them again at night and give them out Monday morning. We lose nearly an hour a week in this way and we have a short enough day as it is, especially when I have an Entrance class.(Grade VII). There have been two seats broken, hymn books torn in two, and obscene words and pictures written in them. They are continually scratching their names on the desks with nails and pins. I have coaxed, warned, and threatened. I have reported it to the agent but it still continues.

Can you advise me what I can do to prevent the damaging of the school property at these meetings.

Some time ago I sent in a requisition for books, etc. I have received the envelopes asked for. Is it your intention to let me have the books asked for?

I am studying extra-murally for my Ontario First class certificate. May I have time off in June to write these examinations somewhere else in Ontario?

I am enclosing a report of parents and pupils with a note on each one. Thanking you for your courtesy and awaiting your reply,

I am,

Very truly yours,

Albert E. Smith.
Oka, February 12, 1934.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 8th instant enclosing a communication received at Ottawa from Mr. A. E. Smith of Oka in which the teacher deals with different subjects. As requested by yours I submit you a report and return the letter herewith.

Mr. Smith claims that last Fall when I gave news that there would not be any general clothing distribution a few families provided their children with clothing. According to the teacher these children are attending regularly when weather permits. Mr. Smith seems to be displeased because some children who have been supplied with shoes etc., are not attending regularly and he gives as example the case of Mrs. Samuel Nicolas' children who are not regular at School after having been provided with clothing. Mr. Smith is of the opinion that the children attending regularly should be treated like the Nicolas and he believes in a distribution to all or nothing at all.

Relative to the above mentioned statements by the teacher I beg to say that I do not agree on every point with him. I am against a general distribution of clothing to the children because when it takes place we help every child regardless of the fact that a good number of them are not very needy and also because the parents would not supply anything to their children in future, even if they could afford to, as they are inclined to rely only on the Dept. for everything they need, but I am in favor of considering each case individually taking into consideration the circumstances and the needs of every particular case. In December 1930 a general distribution was made for all the Indian children attending the Schools at Oka. This necessitated an expense of over $900 and the attendance was lower than last year 1933 when not more than $175.00 was spent for these same pupils.

In connection with the case of Mrs. S. Nicolas I beg to refer you to my letter 64-20 dated January 16th last. Because these children who were in need were supplied with shoes and did not go to School after is not a reason to supply those going regularly and not in need of clothing nor footwear.

The teacher also informs you that the Council and especially Harry Oke have been withholding the distribution of clothing and is also the cause of the discontinuance of the mid-day lunch. He claims that Oke is working his way to have his sister appointed at his place etc. Mr. Smith claims that the report made by the council last Spring pertaining to the early closing of the School was a falsehood. The teacher also reports that Mr. Whitehead is supposed to have said.

In reply to this I beg to say that the teacher's statement relative to H. Oke is apt to give you the impression that your Agent is influenced by some Indians when making reports and recommendations. The recommendations against a general distribution of clothing to the children and for the discontinuance of the mid-day lunch
were not made by the Council nor H. Oke but solely by myself as Agent and without consulting any of the Councillors. I do not need any Indians to advise me as to reports and recommendations as I am aware of my responsibilities.

Relative to the Council resolution last Spring against the early closing of the School I beg to let you know that this protest was founded and that the School was closed too early in the afternoon.

Mr. Smith does not seem to be in very good terms with Rev. Mr. Whitebean and H. Oke, but as this has not anything to do with the affairs of this Agency I do not want to have anything to do with it. As to Mr. Smith's statement that several persons are after his position I beg to say that it is the first time I hear about it. This man seems to pay too much attention to gossip.

The teacher also asks you as to the necessity of the prayer meetings at the School. He claims that the children are losing at least one hour a week on account of that and that the Indians make damages in the class. The aim of the teacher, who is also the janitor, in reporting this is to have the meetings stopped by the Department. I have often visited the School and I have noticed that the class where the meetings are held are not more damaged than any other class where there is not any gatherings. I have often been approached by Mr. Smith to make recommendations to the Dept. in order to prevent these prayer meetings at the Country School.

If, to please the teacher, the Department was ordering the discontinuance of the prayer meetings at the School, it would certainly bring some protestations from the Board of the Church and would also give ground to very unpleasant publicity. The majority of the Indians belonging to the United Church are living in the country near the School, and it is more convenient for them to go there for the meetings during the week than to come to the Church located in the Village, four miles from the School. The less we interfere with religious matters the better it is.

As to the time Mr. Smith the teacher claims the children are loosing I do not see why this is allowed by him, as Mr. Smith the teacher should teach until four o'clock in the afternoon and after four Mr. Smith the janitor should fix everything up himself for the meetings. The only reason for such a complaint from Mr. Smith is that it gives him a little more work as janitor being obliged to sweep the floors after each meeting.

Your obedient servant

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs.
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir:

I beg to transmit you herewith the resolutions passed at the meeting of the Okn Elected Council held on the 7th instant for the month of March 1934. The members present were Harry Oke, Willie Cree and Laurence Etienne.

It was proposed by Harry Oke and seconded by Willie Cree; that the Dept be asked to investigate the way the Country School is conducted by the actual teacher Mr.A.E.Smith. This Council is of the opinion that the attendance is very low at this School owing to improper methods of teaching; the teacher does not encourage the children attending the School. We, the Councillors, claim that recently one pupil, Walter Martin, received bruises on the back from the teacher and previous to this there has been several similar cases; we also claim that the teacher locks the class-room doors and that some children have been kept from attending the toilets the result of this being that some pupils have wet themselves in class. The teacher has impressed the people that he is not working for their welfare but for his own. We find by the children that he has not made any progress in educating and teaching them. He has found to be inclined to laziness. He does not give his full attention to his pupils while in class; he goes in and out of the class-room as he pleases. Furthermore we claim that he has no respect for religion. For over forty years a prayer service is held in the School house and we never had any trouble. Lately he spoke of having these meetings discontinued. Now he annoys the people while the meetings are held by opening his radio full blast, banging the doors and other mean things. The congregation can hardly hear the preaching an account of the radio. The Council believe its duty to report to the Department such proceedings. We believe something should be done. In the past the Dept.has moved a teacher for less complaints. We believe the only remedy is to move him from here. He has been here for over three years and that is much too long as we think that the children are only loosing time.

I am sending you the above resolution without omitting a word of the Council's claims but I beg to inform you that I investigated as to the veracity of the statements made in this resolution.

It is true that the attendance is very low at this School; one day only one pupil was present, but according to the teacher this is due to the work of some Indians who are against him. Mr.Smith claims that this is due to the fact that he refused to teach Sunday School.

Relative to the bruises that Walter Martin is supposed to have received the teacher claims that he never slapped him on the back but only on the hands when this boy disobeyed him. He also denied to have refused to his pupils the attending of the toilets. As to his going in and out of the class room he claims that when he leaves the class it is only for a moment and only when necessary.

The teacher admitted that he opened his radio while the prayer meetings were held but denied that it was playing full blast; Mr.Smith claims that there
there are prayer services on the air, that he wants to hear at the same hour the local meetings are held. He also stated that he particularly likes the program "Amos and Andy" but this that this program is at the same hour of the meeting. The teacher told me that he would not keep his radio closed on account of the meeting.

However since I went at the School for the investigation Mr. Smith did not open his radio during the meetings. As told in a previous letter the teacher is not going along very well with some Indians of this Band and also with the local minister Mr. Whitehead. This stated when Mr. Smith refused to teach Sunday School and the result of this ill-feeling is that the parents are not sending their children to School regularly. The Indians of this Band also seem to be under the impression that a three years stage at this School is the limit.

On the other hand, although the Council's protest seems to contain some exaggerations, I believe the teacher has not always done what he should have.

However if things do not improve within a month from now I will ask you to send an official of the Department to visit the School as it is impossible to let things go as they are now.

I would also kindly suggest you to get a report from Mr. Brady Provincial Inspector for the Protestant Schools of this Province relative to the progress made by the pupils of the Oka Country School.

Sir,

I am sorry that I forgot to go to your office when I was out this morning. You can send in those report forms with the mail this next week as I shall need them then in order to make out my report on attendance. I got the candies O.K.

I am writing you now concerning the children of Martin Martin. You may send this letter to the Department if you wish. These two children both boys Walter aged 13 and Llewellyn aged 9 are a continual source of trouble not only for me but for the rest of the children in the school. They are not respectful to me. When I punish them as at times all children must be punished, they call me names in school and shout vile language at me not only in English but in Indian and in French. When they are made to behave in school they go home and tell their parents and they take the children's part. Last winter when I whipped the oldest boy his mother came down to the school and called me such vile names that I cannot send them through the mail and I would at any time hesitate to repeat them. Mr. Martin has threatened dire things to me should I report the children to the Department. Shortly after Mrs. Martin had visited me last winter I found a note pinned on the school door. It was printed with lead pencil on wrapping paper and read, "You go soon or you be sorry." This bothered me for some time and at last I burnt it but I am of the opinion that it came from the Martins. I cannot prove this however, and we may let it pass. Well last Monday I just had to use the strap on Llewellyn Martin. He would not do anything that I asked him and he kept everyone else in a turmoil in school. He went home and has never come back. Neither has Walter. Of course they do that every time that I resort to corporal punishment. People have told me that they are not coming back again.

I am writing to tell you and the Department that I now refuse to allow these children to come to this school any longer. I do not feel that we should be expected to put up with children in school when their presence tends to lower the moral tone of the school. I must look after the morals of the other children.
and I feel that the children of Martin Martin are not fit to associate with the others. I hope that you and the Department will take into consideration the fact that the Martins are and always have been a breeding place for trouble. The children are only following in the footsteps of their parents. If I could teach the children to be anything higher I wouldn't mind them at school. But it is impossible for me to teach them anything because they know that they do not have to do as I say. However if they stay at home they are a nuisance to the other children when they are coming to or going from the school. Last fall when I had some trouble with them I mentioned to Mr. Martin that they should be in a reform school. He replied to the effect that he would not send them and that the Government could not do anything without his permission. He said they could do as they liked here and the Government had no control of them because they belonged to the Life or old custom chiefs. I doubt this but did not tell him.

Mrs. Smith has been a witness to all these doings for the past four years and she can say that I am not exaggerating any. In fact I am putting the facts as mild as possible.

Having stated the case as clearly as I can in such a short space I now leave the outcome to you and the Department of Indian Affairs. I refuse to have anything more to do either with the children or with the parents in question. If they want to come to school there will have to be a new teacher and that will not please the rest of the parents in this section of the reserve.

Thanking you and the Department for all past favours and wishing you both the compliments of the Season,

I am,

Very truly yours,

Albert E. Smith,
Teacher-in-charge.

My dear Mr. Fenner,

Many years have passed since I saw you at Ottawa the last time. It is such a long time that I doubt you will have difficulty in remembering me. Let me introduce myself. I was educated eleven or twelve years ago and was employed by your department as teacher at the Oka County School. I received the appointment through the Rev. Mr. Smith, then a pastor at Montreal. I came to him seeking employment from my home in New Hampshire, he answered my request and kindly offered me the position. I accepted his offer and moved away from home or friend and took up teaching at Oka County School.

I have been there two years now and was appointed as teacher at Oka County School and taking an active part in church work under the leadership of the Rev. Mr. Smith. I feel that over these two years I have met a difficult task, but I have not faltered. I have felt that position was a difficult one, and how unfulfilled I feel for that position. My education was insufficient but my experience with life was pitifully small. It required a man with more experience than I had with a broader understanding of the people and their mode of living and thinking. Mr. Smith has never forgotten the debt of gratitude I feel after a more experienced and older man took my place. I gave my best but at the time my best was not good enough. Mr. Smith understood and I will always remember his last words to me; they have helped me many times during the past year, and in spite of everything I have seen in Boston ever since, I have enjoyed a fair measure of success, but I have never been happy there, and can never forget my promise to my God made many years ago and every day I feel a stronger urge to leave it all and return to the work I love and to a complete fulfillment of that purpose.

May I hope I have lived up to your expectations? I have written you this letter. I hope you will understand, if I could talk with you I could express myself more freely. I am now very busy with my family and a little girl. I am married with one child, she is five years old, and as I watch her day by day I am convinced that she will grow into a fine young woman. I am grateful for the opportunity to start over again and make of my life what God would have it.

Sincerely yours,
Selby Boucher

11. Parts of the Plant: Identification and use to the plant of root, stem, leaf, flower, seed and fruit.

Note: Courses "A" and "C" will be taken in alternate years. Course "B" will be taken every year.

Topics should be taught in any order which conforms to the seasons or when opportunity offers for a good lesson.
COURSE A.

1. Reasons for Farming: Independence, self-respect, thrift, industry, self-maintenance.

2. The Farm: Kinds; Grain, fruit, poultry, mixed: Descriptions.

3. Farmer's Work: Preparing soil, sowing, reaping, threshing, storing, repairing harness and machinery, farm chores.

4. Farm Animals: Cattle, horses, sheep, hogs, poultry. Identification and description of main types of each.

5. Farm Machinery: HAND POWER. Seeder, seythe, cradle, rake, drags, hoe, spade, wire-stretcher, stump-puller, saw, axe, forks, shovel, crowbar, separator, churn, flail, etc. HORSE or ENGINE POWER. Plough, disc, harrow, spring and drag tooth, seeder, roller, mower, binder, rake, leader, hay fork, feed chopper, thresher, buzz saw.

6. Farm Buildings: Number, size, floors, lighting, ventilation.

7. Work of the Farmer's Wife: Cooking, cleaning, mending, knitting, Making of Butter, bread, family clothes, chores. Leisure.

8. Grains: Classes and uses of each.

9. Milk and Cream: Uses and care.

10. The Garden: Vegetables, kinds, planting and care.

11. The Farm Beautiful: Paint. Flowers. Pictures. General repairs.

COURSE B.

1. The School Fair: Seeds, classes of exhibits, raising money, etc.

2. The School Garden: Size, plots, vegetables, flowers.

3. The School Beautiful: Window boxes, border beds, trees and shrubs, bulbs, annuals, perennials.

4. Cleanliness and Tidiness: On farm as well as at school.

5. Bulletin Library: Sources, series, lending, checking.

Dear Sir,

In writing this letter to you I feel that no apology is necessary. By a perusal of the following pages you will find (1) My report of what I have successfully accomplished in the teaching of Agriculture in the school on the Lake of Two Mountains Reserve here. (2) My reasons for making the teaching of Agriculture obligatory in all Indian Schools. (3) My success in the organization of the School Fair which I have conducted since 1932. (4) My plan for the organization and supervision of the subject in all its aspects in the schools.

(1) During my past six years experience as teacher here I feel that I have made an impression not only on the farming habits of the child but also upon those of the parent. In the rotation of crops, care of farm animals and working in the right season there has been a decided change for the better. It has furnished many points of contact between the parents and myself. It has been to a great extent responsible for the high average attendance of pupils at school because the pupils have enjoyed the discussions and the after class work which they have been called upon to perform. Both pupils and parents see that there is nothing degrading in farming as a life work. These are a few of the benefits which I have derived from the teaching of Agriculture.

(2) (a) In the first place the indian must be, not coaxed or wheedled into farming, but must be brought to realize the advantages of farming. This can best be done by the teaching and supervision of Agriculture in the Day schools on the reserves. This can be done only by sympathetic teachers who understand the indian and who are satisfied to "Make haste slowly."

(b) While the course of study and the school fair scheme is fine for white schools it is not fair to expect the indian children to join a white school fair and compete with the children of that school whose forefathers were farming before the indian was discovered. However, under correct guidance, coaching, and teaching there is no doubt that the indian will in the near
future measure up to and in many ways surpass his white neighbour as a farmer.

(c) We are continually exhorting the Indians to be as far as possible, self-supporting. This can better be done by teaching the future Indians in our schools of today.

(d) As an aid to the class-room work of the teacher, the School Fair must take a prominent place because Indian children more than any others must learn to do by doing, and they, by earning a little prize money, see the economic value of farm labour.

(e) The care of school plants and fence border flower beds tends to lighten the tedium of every day classes and makes for more beautiful surroundings.

(f) There are very few children who do not relish a discussion on farm animals and their care. I can truthfully say that the lessons in Agriculture have assisted me greatly in the keeping up of the attendance.

(g) Next to the three R's comes Agriculture. Because it will be of greatest value in after life owing to the fact that so few Indian children have the perseverance to continue studies past the public or elementary schools.

(3) After being appointed as teacher in this school in the fall of 1930 it did not take me long to see that here the need for the teaching of Agriculture was very great. Accordingly I mapped out a course which was in many ways similar to that as set forth in the Ontario Teacher's Manual on the subject. (Copy is enclosed.) Hatch and Haslewood's text was, I thought, unsuitable for the pupils' use so I have used The New Agriculture by Waters, which we used in the training classes at the North Bay Normal School. I find that I have had more success in giving a well prepared lesson than in the use of the text book in the hands of the pupils.

During the Fall of 1931 I saw that something more was necessary than just the class-room lessons. The School Fair was the answer. By this they would be able to put into practice some of the ideas gained in class. Here I was handicapped because the Quebec Dept. of Education and Agriculture does not foster the idea of school fairs as does the Ontario Government. However during my ten years experience in the Ontario Public Schools I had had a great deal of experience in the work of the school fair.

A private School Fair was the answer to my quest. I talked it over with different ones on the Reserve and got very little encouragement, but having the courage of my convictions I obtained the help of three young men and we put on a play. Nothing very uplifting, but it brought the necessary funds for the idea.
Using this money I bought seeds and distributed them to the children in the Spring of 1932. I saved $5.75 for prize money in September and with the balance I purchased a small silver cup with the words OKA COUNTRY SCHOOL FAIR suitably engraved upon it. I typed out the prize list and instructions, one for each child. They have been similar to the one for this year which is enclosed.

Judging is done by three of the Indians who show more of an interest than the others. I usually spend a few hours coaching them the day before the fair. My system of numbers on the exhibits makes it difficult for the judges to tell to whom the exhibits belong. The prize money is given out the day of the Fair, the announcement is made as to who is the holder of the cup for the coming year. I give a short talk on why such an exhibit got First prize and another one none and so on. I also give as much information as I can to the grown ups regarding their work on the farm and in the garden. This year Mrs. Smith and I gave a practical demonstration of the canning machine. Last year it was a talk on drying vegetables and fruits for winter use.

Concerts, suppers and socials are means of raising money for the Fair. Every year more parents visit the school on Fair Day to examine the exhibits and every year there is greater competition for the cup. The School Fair has come to be considered a permanent fixture here and is thought to be as necessary as the Day or Sunday Schools. I hold with that opinion myself.

Besides the School Fair I have, contrary to the general opinion, made a success of fence border flower plots. A farmer loaned us a few barrowfuls of manure. The bigger boys and I do the digging. I bought a dozen gladioli and different Indians offered parts of their pet perennials. We have now a lovely border on one side consisting of Gladioli and Delphiniums. On the other side we have Sweet William, Gaillardia, and Dianthus with a rose tree in the centre. A small lilac bush is expected to bloom near the flagpole next spring. The front border as yet is just mixed annuals but we have sufficient perennial plants in a neighbouring garden to make a nice show along the front next year and in years to come.

It is surprising how carefully the children avoid the border beds when at play. They know that the flowers not only give joy to them but also to passing tourists who stop to remark on the beauty of the borders. And Indians do like to be noticed and show not only themselves but their handiwork.
In respect to the organization and supervision of the subject in the Indian Schools I may make the following statements which are merely suggestions of what might be done.

An experienced teacher of the subject could be appointed as Director and stationed at Brantford or London so that he could visit the schools in that area at least once a year. He would be supplied with a mimeograph with which he would make copies of lesson plans on different topics on the course of study. He would be in a position to spend a certain amount of time answering letters from teachers regarding the subject. Other schools in the dominion could be kept track of by means of communication with the teachers. When funds were available the director could visit other schools in other provinces or a director could be appointed for each of the provinces. But for the present to see how the thing would work it would be possible for one man to handle it and if he could not visit the schools personally he could do a great deal by letter to make the teachers and pupils Agriculture conscious. The salary and expenses would, perhaps, amount to $2,500 or $3,000 per year but I feel that it would be money well spent.

After having read these reports and suggestions should you and your Department see it advisable to go into the matter more fully and at length I should be willing, on any Saturday, to arrange with you and those members of your Department who have control of Indian Education and funds.

References as to my ability may be had by writing to my present inspector W.H. Brady, 4222 Old Orchard Ave., Montreal. As to my character you might inquire of Colonel, the Honourable James Arthurs our past member for my home constituency of Parry Sound and who has since been appointed to the Senate.

Please believe me when I state that this communication is being written with a view to the betterment of the indian and his status as a member of the community. We must bear in mind that the true missionary should teach the indian to live without him not with him.

Thank you for your kind attention and may you give this your earnest consideration,

Faithfully yours,

[Signature]

Sir,-

The following report on my recent visit of inspection to the Oka, P.Q., Agency is respectfully submitted.

OKA COUNTRY SCHOOL.

Has 55 on the roll. The average attendance for February was 24. This is lower than usual owing to an epidemic of whooping cough, measles and colds. Attendance is irregular. There is no truant officer and the agent gives little attention to this part of his duty. The School buildings are in good repair and well kept up.

At this school some handicraft work is taught. The pupils are very clever at this work and enjoy it. Mr. Smith is enthusiastic about developing it. He expressed his intention of taking the summer course in vocational training for teachers in Toronto this summer.

Pupils at both schools are comfortably clothed. Cod liver oil is given daily and hot soup at noon. There are no signs of undernourishment among them. On the whole they are doing very well and making progress in their work. It would mean much to these boys and girls in after life if they could be given more instruction to develop their active ability along manual training lines.

Dear Sir,

I would like to thank you for your work in having the furnace installed in this building. It is proving entirely satisfactory and keeps the residence and school very comfortable. It also saves us a great deal of time and labour and will, I believe, save on the fuel bill also.

I should like, also, to express my gratitude to both you and Miss K. Moodie for having sent the loom here. It has given us a great deal of extra work and caused us to have to crowd our living quarters somewhat but it has proved its worth to us. We are instructing four of the school children in the work of setting up the loom and weaving. There is only one woman, as yet, who has asked to learn it. Others come and see it and either think it would be too hard to learn or else they are afraid to learn it for fear they would lose their relief if they did do so. We have finished the towels which Miss Moodie left on the loom for us and we have set on another warp for sharpening bars. The design is the Monk's Belt. Our variations of the pattern are working out very beautifully. We will need more warp of some kind as soon as we get the bars finished. The boys have made a warping board, spool rack and spools, winder, and raddle. I believe that the small looms would be better for a place like this. If one was sent we could duplicate it any number of times so that each house could have one. I have bought sufficient lumber to make a large loom and will start on it as soon as I get caught up with the work in the classes in school. Then you can send this big loom to another reserve and we will have one like it of our own.
A couple of years ago I mentioned the fact to you that I would soon have to get to another centre where my son could attend High School. He really should have gone this year but we didn't want to send him to a town and among strangers. I spoke to Miss Moodie about our predicament and she seemed to realize that something would have to be done about us. I like the Indian work and would like to remain in Indian schools as I believe I have the knack of giving them what they need. I have made a success of the work here in the past eight years and I feel that I could do the same elsewhere. I'd like you to write to an inspector and get his idea of my work here. His address is W.H. Brady, T.A., 4222 Old Orchard Ave., Montreal, P.Q. Is there any possibility of there being a handicraft centre opened on one of the bigger reserves where I might fit in as an instructor in handwork, weaving, etc. I hate to give up here now that we have been made so comfortable and have worked so hard to get the pupils along to where they are manageable. The people, too, like me because they elected me to the Board of Stewards of the church with three votes more than were polled for anyone else. I find that we will have to move by September so that Gerald may go to High School. He has spent two years in Grade VII now. I'd like him to take a technical course if possible. I'm sure that you and Miss Moodie will try to solve my problem for me.

When I got your last letter I went to see Dunice Laforce. She was busy and was having a lesson made for herself and did not see interested so we went ahead alone. Made a couple of blunders but eventually got it under way and now we understand the work better. We have Worst's book now and have sent Miss Moodie to Rev. C.D. Strapp as you requested.

In woodwork I am having the boys specialize in the making of wooden toys and lawn ornaments. There is a good future in that line. The girls are doing cloth toys. They sure enjoy it. I have very good books on toy making.

In closing please let me thank you again for all you have done for us.

Yours truly,

Albert E. Smith.

MEMORANDUM:

MR. HOEY

Re: Visit to the Oka Village and Oka Country Schools

The Oka Country School under the direction of John Thomas Angus was inspected in the morning, between nine and twelve-thirty. Mr. Angus, although possessing no professional training is making a success of this school. The attendance seems better than when I visited the first time and the spirit in the classroom has changed for the better. The attendance, however, could still be greatly improved. I advised Mr. Angus to take a normal training as soon as he possibly could, as it would be to his advantage if he really wishes to remain in the teaching profession. The school itself is greatly in need of decoration, the exterior and the interior. In order to protect the building it should be painted exteriorly as soon as funds are available. The interior is a natural finish in dull brown. A light color would greatly increase the light in this classroom. I have asked Mr. Angus to give Agent Brisebois an estimate for the painting of both the Country and the Village School. Screens should be provided for the windows.

It might be advisable to divide our schools into three or four groups and have one group completely repaired one year, the second group another year, etc. The fifth year the cycle would start over. This, I believe, would prove less expensive and our buildings would be in a better condition. Surroundings have a great deal of influence on pupils.

Mr. Angus is going to take charge of the school gardens, both for the Village and the Country Schools during the summer holidays.

OKA VILLAGE SCHOOL

The Oka Village School under the direction of Miss Doris Mary Diabo was visited during the afternoon of the same day. Miss Diabo is making a success of this school. The attendance has increased since she has taken charge, but still an improvement could be made. Her pupils are progressing satisfactorily. Screens for six windows of the Oka Village School are required.

Reading tests were taken in both schools, in grades two, three and four. The pupils of second grade have done exceptionally well in reading grade and reading age. This applies to both schools. Grades three and four are well classified in reading grade but are rather old as far as reading age.

Most of the children here have been marked up into grades they definitely do not qualify for. Since January I have tried much as was possible to bring them ahead all the world about. Dear Sir,

I am writing to ask you a favor. May I have an advance of $50.00 on my October salary, at this time.

I presume you are aware that teachers of Indian day schools qualify under the cost-of-living bonus. At the present time this is 11% of your salary. Payment of the bonus will be made at the end of each month.

Dear Sir,

I thought I should write to let you know so you could enquire if the cheque had been issued.

Ottawa,
November 5, 1942.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 4th instant, with reference to the non receipt of your October salary cheque. I regret very much the delay in issuing the cheques for the month of October, but they have now gone forward and yours has no doubt reached you by this time. The delay was due to two factors; first, the increase in the cost-of-living bonus and, second, the new deductions for income tax. These two changes involve a great deal of computation and, as a result, issue of the cheques was delayed. I am assured that there will be no further difficulty in this regard during the balance of the academic year.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. C.J. Keddy,
Teacher,

Indian Country School,
Oka, Que.,
April 1st, 1939.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa

Dear Sir,

In your letter of Jan. 10th, 1939, you informed me that the requirement for a new school building here had been noted for the estimates for this year.

There are one or two suggestions I should like to make regarding the plans for this building, but I have not made these suggestions partly because I feared to be presumptuous, and partly because I imagine that certain plans are in existence, any departure from which would be impracticable. I desire to ask if the Department will allow me the privilege of making these suggestions for what they are worth, unless the matter is already settled beyond possibility of alteration.

If the Department cares to receive these suggestions I shall consider it a very great favour.

In the meantime there are three matters in connection with the project which I am sure you will not mind my bringing to your attention, the more so because I know of no-one else who will do so if I do not. They are as follows:

1. The necessity for an enlarged or new site.
   The present school grounds are only 78 ft x 64 ft., and we have not sufficient room for recreational purposes. The school is less than thirty feet from the road, and the toilets are only ten feet away from the school. In some ways, an enlarged playground is even more necessary than a new building.

2. An arrangement whereby school can be continued in the old building while the new building is in course of erection.
   If the new school is on another site this will be easy enough, but I draw attention to the matter.
because I do not wish the children to lose time if it can be avoided and because once they get out of the habit of attending it is a difficult matter to bring them back. It would be a very satisfactory situation if we could start school as usual in September 1st, either in the old building or the new, and, if in the old building, move to the new when it is ready.

3. The disposal of the old building.

This question is bound to arise and the solution may not be easy to find. A certain section of the people,—the reactionary element—are quite anxious to be able to use it for their own purposes, which would include activities not in favour of the Department. Furthermore, the question as to the actual ownership of the building may arise, a question about which I am not competent to write but of which the Department should be informed.

I have placed these matters before the Department somewhat hesitatingly, and I shall be very much obliged if you will inform me if the suggestions I mention in the first part of my letter will be acceptable.

Your respectfully,

H. E. Eburne.

Teacher.

Dear Sir,

I have to thank you for permission to forward one or two suggestions with regard to the new school here.

Before availing myself of the permission I would desire to say that the statement I made in my letter of Sept 6th 1926 (see your reply, Sept 15th 1926, 30-1-5) with reference to the consolidation of the work here apply with increased force today, but the people are not at all in favour of such a plan, and I am not raising the matter again because I feared without their approval it would merely invite failure.

In conversation with the Superintendent of Education two years ago, I was given to understand that the school to be built here would include a teacher's residence. I am not quite sure now whether such is advisable. I cannot help thinking that if a lady teacher should be appointed to the school at some late date, it would certainly not be advisable for her to live alone, especially if she is young. On the other hand, a man generally prefers not to be bothered with a residence, and prefers to board. If it were possible to build a residence large enough for a man and his wife, both of whom would be engaged in teaching, with the library and domestic subjects, such would be a very satisfactory solution, but I doubt whether the Department contemplate such action.

Whether the school contains a residence or not, I would very earnestly plead for additional rooms to be used as work rooms and recreation rooms. I suggest one room as a work room for the girls, which could also be used as a dining room and a recreation room in wet weather (a rarely needed provision), and one room for the boys, perhaps located in the basement, which would serve the same purpose except that it is a dining room and might also be used for scout and club purposes. A kitchenette or hutchette should be attached to the girls' room. While I have done as good work as I could do here, yet I feel that our methods have been a little too bookish and I would be delighted to have the
provision of these additional rooms to work out some larger projects. The cost of such rooms would add only slightly to the cost of the school, while the saving to the town from itself and its equipment would make up for it in a few years. If an additional room or two is still thought necessary, it could be placed above the other in somewhat the same way (on a smaller scale) as the school at Hubert River (Man.).

In the same connection, I would suggest a really adequate basement, to be used as a playground in wet weather and for a furnace if the Department desires to install one. While the question of a furnace may be closed up with the question of a basement, yet if there is to be a basement, which I very much hope, I am afraid that the floor would be flooded if the schoolhouse was only stove heated.

May I add that the question of protection in wet weather is a very live question, and I seriously doubt whether any school should be built without such provision. The schoolroom itself is certainly not the place for it.

Is it possible to install electric light in the school? At present, while the wires do not pass by the school, they come to within 15 miles west of us and 2 miles east of us, although operated by separate companies. If the school were to make common cause with neighboring farmers, I think the thing could be quite easily done.

Mr. Indian Agent Harbour is in a position in which he could quite conveniently raise the matter with both the farmers concerned and the Electric Lighting Companies. The advantages are so obvious that I do not need to explain them, especially if we do as I have done for three years—night work with students over school age. But my real reason is that I could operate a lantern and picture and give to the children a much wider knowledge of general things than I have so far been able to do. I worked out these lantern lessons a few years ago and I have found nothing since that equals them.

I desire to add one or two minor suggestions which might possibly be overlooked if they are not mentioned:

1. The necessity for a well.
   - At present we have no choice of two wells belonging to the house. One gives us very bad smelling water and the other is just outside a stable.

2. Plenty of cupboard space.
   - This can be so much more easily provided when
The school is being built now at a later time.

The provision of a map case, or at least, spring rollers for our maps.

This is a little expensive at first, but the saving on the maps themselves is surely made up in a few years.

There are many things that I have not mentioned, such as blackboard space, window space, window shades, etc., but these things you will not expect me to mention, as I well know that the Department takes them all into consideration when building schools. I would not have presumed to make the suggestions I have made except for the fact that I am in a position to see things from the local standpoint, and that I know that both the suggestions I have made and the circumstances here are a little unusual.

I apologize for writing a letter and thank the Department for giving me the opportunity. I hope that what I have said may be of some slight service.

Yours respectfully,

H.E. Elmore
Teacher

Dear Sir,

It has come to my knowledge that Mr. Noah Coronthi, the newly elected chief here, has set himself in opposition to the project of a new school here. It is not the first time that this man has come out in opposition to educational progress here, but it is particularly regrettable that he has done so in this instance. As far as I can understand his only object is to support a close relative who recently lost the post of joker at the school.

I have to advise you that Mr. Coronthi represents - in this instance - no-one but himself. The people are not only overwhelmingly in favour of it, but are keenly anxious to see the school built. He certainly would have
no following in the council on such a question.

I most earnestly beg the Department not to allow any representation from this man to stand in the way of such an advantageous project as the new school will be.

I regret troubling the Department in such a matter, but it would be most unfortunate if any foolish statements by one man should interfere with plans already made.

Yours respectfully,

H. E. Eburne,
Teacher

Dear Sir,

A few weeks ago, before I was aware that there was to be a change of teacher here, I had printed 250 copies of the enclosed report form, for which I have received a bill of $4.50. As I shall not personally use these forms and as they will be left here for the use of the new teacher, I venture to ask whether I may submit this bill to the Indian Agent for payment by the Department.

At the same time I incurred an expenditure of $10. by taking a party of my children to Montreal to attend an educational exhibition, - an international gymnasia. The result of their visit, which included twelve scholars, has been very gratifying indeed and from every point of view was well justified. Seeing that I am not continuing as teacher I shall not reap any advantage from the expenditure and I should like to be able to send this bill also to the Indian Agent.

I am fully aware that these expenditures were not authorized, but at the time I incurred them I expected to benefit by the expenditure which I intended to meet myself. Now that circumstances have changed I shall be obliged if you will permit me to charge them to the Department.

Yours respectfully,

N. E. Elmore,
Teacher.

Sir:

The Department has received your telegram, protesting against the reconstruction of the Country Indian Day School. In reply I have to state that the present building is no longer suitable for the conduct of successful work, and the Department is proceeding to demolish it without delay, as you were informed by our officers who visited the reserve yesterday. MEMO. FOR FILE:

I have examined the old files which have reference to the beginning of the OKA COUNTRY Indian Day School, and I find that two members of the Band each gave a part of a lot to the Department of Indian Affairs and the Methodist Church for a mission and the school. It is probable that the first building, which was erected in 1880, was constructed by the members of the Band, assisted by the Department from Band funds or other monies and by the Methodist Church. In 1897, when there was practically a reconstruction, $100 only was charged to Band Funds, the rest being taken from Vote. In 1912, there was a further reconstruction and the funds were taken from Vote.

Oka, August 17th, 1929.

Sir,

Re: Country school building

Simon K. Simon came to the office this morning and told me he could not sell the piece of land at the rear of the Country school lot; he gave me the enclosed letter which has been written by the Life Chiefs.

With regards to MM. Marinier they told me last night that Mr. Joseph Marinier would work at the building as foreman, provided the Department would take every materials from them, that is: timber, nails, tar paper paint, castings etc., etc., etc.

Kindly let me know your decision at your earliest convenience and also tell me what steps to take if the Life Chiefs gang object when we will proceed to the demolition of the old building.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

With further reference to your letter of the 17th instant, concerning the building of the Oka Country Indian Day School and teacher's residence. I have to inform you that if any of the Indians interfere with the contractors when they are demolishing the old building or erecting the new one, you should immediately get in touch with the nearest detachment of the R.C.M.P. and ask them for assistance. You will advise the Department at once if you find this action is necessary. You should explain to any interested Indians that the Department has power, under the law, to effect improvements to a school and that the money for these improvements is entirely from Parliamentary Appropriation and not at all from the funds of the band.

Sir,

An inquiry has been received from the teacher of the Oka Country Indian Day School, requesting to be informed whether or not a midday meal will be served to the pupils during the winter months, the same as was done last year. EXTRACT from Report of Inspector J. W. McQuat,
dated April 10th, 1930, on his inspection of the
Oka Country Indian Day School.

There is a new school building and a pair of
outhouses.

There was a bad mistake made by some one in planning
your classroom. The teacher has to have her desk at the en-
trance between the two entrance doors, where she is in the
midst of the cold and all the noise of pupils coming and going,
while she can see nothing going on. The school should have had
the light on the opposite side and the teacher at the rear of
the room. I am informed that the plan was drawn right but that
it was reversed in its erection.

Besides, the new well is too near the privy pits,
that were closed. There was water in the basement on Apr. 10/30.

Some of the seats are too near the stove. The stove
needs a tin or galvanized jacket to protect pupils who sit near
it from the excessive heat. It is no place for the stove up in
the middle of the classroom. Its place is a schoolroom is near
the front door, where the cold air is found. But that is where
the teacher has to have her desk according to the plan of the
school. People, who presume to plan a schoolroom, should know
better than to outline such a contradiction of schoolroom
principles, for everything has been misplaced, the teacher, the
pupils, the stove, the windows, the entrances, all turned around.
Ottawa, May 13, 1930.

Sir:

I wish to refer to official 20-1-5 of December 17th, last, authorizing you to expend $5.50 installing a rural mail box at the Oka Country Indian Day School. I am informed that this box has not yet been installed. Please take early steps in this connection.

You should also see that the lock on the boys' door is repaired and should report on the school clock. If you believe this could be repaired and properly placed on a shelf, you may take the necessary steps. If you are of the opinion that a new clock is necessary, please let me know at what price you can make purchase.

It is reported that water is lying in the basement of the new school. Will you please take immediate steps to ascertain what is wrong with the drain and let the Department have a report and recommendation without delay. Your early attention is requested.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

F. Harbour, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Oka, P. Q.

Oka, June 5th, 1930.

Sir,

With reference to your letter of the 15th ultimo, I beg to say that the rural mail box is installed at the Oka Indian Country school. The shelf is purchased and the clock is repaired.

As regards to the drain, my opinion is that when it was put up, we had very hard cold weather and the earth used to fill up the ditch of the drain was in lumps so that the air went through and the pipes must be either blocked or broken; the ditch has to be dug again and the pipes inspected; otherwise it will always be the same.

As told on my letter of yesterday, the work will begin on Monday next and in a few days, I shall report further as to the results of the work.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, August 19, 1930.

Sir:

I have to inform you that we are today placing an order with J. Oliver & Sons Ltd., Ottawa, to supply the following single school desks for the use of the Oka Country Indian Day School:

12 No. 3 Oliver single desks,
2 No. 3 rear seats.

These desks will be shipped addressed to you, Como, P.Q., in a knocked down condition, and ink wells are to be supplied with each. Please get in touch with the freight agent at Como and have him inform you as soon as these desks arrive, in order that you can accept delivery and have the desks taken to the school. You should then arrange to have them assembled and set up in the classroom.

The above firm have been requested to make early shipment, and to forward their account, in duplicate, to you. When the desks are received, if in good condition, you should certify the account in the usual manner and send it to the Department for payment.

It is hoped that, when these desks arrive, they will be satisfactory. They are the same type as the single desks at present in use in the school and are to replace a number of the old style double desks. You may dispose of the old double desks that are of no further use in any manner considered advisable by you.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, August 20, 1930.

Sir:

I have to inform you that the Department has decided to continue the hot soup or drink this winter for the pupils of the Oka Country Indian Day School. I believe it would be advisable to supplement the pupils' lunches in this fashion from December first to April 30th.

Miss Simons, the teacher, proposed to teach the girls household management and there will be a course in cooking. She is, therefore, prepared to supervise the preparation of the hot soup or drink, with the help of the older girls. It will not be necessary to engage Mrs. Jos. Simon for the purpose.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
For Secretary.

F. Harbour, Esq.,

Sir:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, requesting to be supplied with lumber to make fence border boxes for flowers, garden seeds and hauling earth.

In this connection it is noted that you are teaching agriculture to the pupils of the Oka Indian Day School, and beautifying the school grounds. If you will make an estimate of the cost of the lumber required and hauling of the earth, and forward same through the office of your local Indian Agent, Mr. F. Harbour, favourable consideration will be given to authorizing him to make the purchase, etc. It is considered unnecessary that a large number of fence boxes be installed. A few arranged along the fence in front of the school should be sufficient.

Regarding the seeds, it is thought that it would not require an expenditure to the amount mentioned by you, viz., $9. You should prepare a list of the seeds required and place the order for same. If you forward payment with the order for the seeds, you should obtain an itemized account, in duplicate, which should be properly receipted, and hand same to the Agent, when a cheque in payment will be forwarded to reimburse you. If it is intended that the Department pay the firm for the seeds, you should also hand the account, in duplicate, to Mr. Harbour, as it is necessary that he certify same.

In future, I would request that you forward all requests for supplies of any nature, and also in regard to any matters in connection with the school, through the office of the local Indian Agent.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

May I ask your consideration on the following:

(b) That a small window be placed in the large clothes-closet of the bed-room upstairs. At present my wife and son and myself occupy the one room which is small and has no system of air circulation. A small window in the store-room on the south side would allow more air to enter the bed-room.

The Department cannot understand your delay in complying with instructions.

The pump in the residence at the Country School is leaking. You will please be good enough to arrange to have this pump repaired and placed in good condition at the earliest possible date. No unnecessary expense should be incurred, and when the pump has been repaired, you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

F. Harbour, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Oka, P.Q.
16th November, 1931.

Memorandum.

On a recent visit to Oka my attention was drawn to the need of a garage at the Country Indian Day School. Mr. Smith has to rent an old building from an adjoining Indian to keep his car in during the winter. A garage is really a necessity here and I would recommend that one be built as soon as funds are available.

Attendance is irregular at this school, some families not sending their children to school. In my report upon this agency I have recommended a monthly patrol by a member of the R.C.M.P. Police in the capacity of truant officer. I believe this would have a very good effect upon the average attendance, particularly of those pupils whose parents are neglectful or in some cases opposed to sending their children.

Inspector.
Country School,
Oka, Que.,
Dec. 3, 1931.

Dear Sir,

As soon as possible I should like to know the amount your department is prepared to allow this school for the purchase of candy for the children's tree at Christmas.

Yours truly,

Albert T. Smith.
